GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 30.03 BONDS OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES; AMOUNT OF.
   (A)   Requirement. Before entering upon the discharge of his duties, each
officer and employee, where such is required by the municipal authority, shall
execute a bond approved according to law in the amount set forth for his
respective office or position.
   (B)   Amount.
      (1)   The bond of the clerk-treasurer of the village is hereby declared
to be in the amount of $5,000.
      (2)   The bond of the secretary to the clerk-treasurer of the village is
hereby declared to be in the amount of $5,000.
      (3)   The bond of the mayor of the village is hereby declared to be in
the amount of $2,000.
      (4)   No other village officers are to be bonded.
(Ord. 8-1980, passed 6-17-80)
§ 30.04 INVESTMENT POLICY.
   (A)   Pursuant to S.B. 81, effective September 27, 1996, and codified as
R.C. § 135.14(N), and R.C. § 135.35(E) and (K), it is the policy of the Village
to invest money of this Village only in:
      (1)   United States treasury securities or any other obligation
guaranteed as to principal and interest by the United States, with a maturity
date of five years or less;
      (2)   Securities directly issued by any federal government agency or
instrumentality;
      (3)   Deposits with a Depository;
      (4)   State of Ohio obligations;
      (5)   Investments made through an eligible institution in a no-load money
market mutual fund consisting exclusively of securities described in (1) and
(2) above and which fund does not include any investment in a derivative;
      (6)   STAR Ohio;
      (7)   Automatic Investment Service Agreements with a Depository; and,
      (8)   Repurchase Agreements with a Depository, as provided for by R.C. §
135.14(E).
   (B)   All brokers, dealers, and financial institutions executing
transactions with this Village shall be required to read this policy, receive a
copy thereof, and acknowledge in writing their receipt and comprehension
thereof.
(Ord. 13-1996, passed 9-17-96; Am. Ord. 6-1997, passed 5-13-97)
§ 30.05 PUBLIC RECORDS POLICY.
   (A)   General policy. It is the belief of the village that openness leads to
a better informed citizenry, which, in turn, leads to better government and
better public policy. Accordingly, it is the policy of the village to strictly
adhere to the state's Public Records Act. All exemptions to openness are to be
construed in their narrowest sense. Any denial of public records in response to
a valid request must be accompanied by an explanation, including legal
authority, as outlined in the Ohio Revised Code. If the request is in writing,
the explanation must also be in writing.
   (B)   Public records.
      (1)   The village, in accordance with the Ohio Revised Code, defines
records as including the following: any document - paper, electronic
(including, but not limited to, e-mail), or other format - that is created or
received by, or comes under the jurisdiction of a public office that documents
the organization, functions, policies, decisions, procedures, operations, or
other activities of the office.
      (2)   All records of the village are public unless they are specifically
exempt from disclosure under the Ohio Revised Code.
   (C)   Records retention. It is the policy of the village that, as requested
by Ohio law, records will be organized and maintained so that they are readily
available for inspection and copying. Record retention schedules are to be
updated regularly and posted prominently.
   (D)   Policy concerning electronic records.
      (1)   Documents in electronic mail format (e-mail) are records as defined
by the Ohio Revised Code when their content relates to the conduct of public
business of the village and are subject to disclosure. E-mail is to be treated
in the same fashion as records in other formats and should follow the same
retention schedules.
      (2)   Records in private e-mail accounts used to conduct public business
are subject to disclosure and all employees or representatives of the village
are instructed to retain their e-mails that relate to public business and copy
them to their business e-mail accounts and/or the designated records custodian.
      (3)   For additional guidance on electronic records, please refer to the
separate policy regarding electronic records (Internet, E-mail, & Online
Services Policy).
   (E)   Records requests. Each request for public records shall be evaluated
for a response using the following guidelines:
      (1)   Although no specific language is required to make a request, the
requester must at least identify the records requested with sufficient clarity
to allow the public office to identify, retrieve, and review the records.
      (2)   If it is not clear what records are being sought, the records
custodian will contact the requester for clarification, and will assist the
requester in revising the request by informing the requester of the manner in
which the office keeps the records.
      (3)   The requester does not have to put a records request in writing,
and does not have to provide his or her identity or the intended use of the
requested public record, except as required below.
      (4)   An individual may be limited to ten records requests per month that
are to be forwarded by mail unless the request certifies in writing that the
records will not be used for commercial purposes.
      (5)   Public records will be available for inspection during regular
business hours (8:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.), with the exception of published
holidays.
      (6)   Public records will be made available for inspection in a prompt
manner.
      (7)   Copies of public records will be made available within a reasonable
period of time.
      (8)   Each request shall be evaluated, on an individual basis, regarding
the estimated length of time required to gather and duplicate the records (see
definitions of routine and non-routine requests below).
   (F)   Prompt inspection, or copies within a reasonable period of time.
      (1)   There is no set, predetermined time period for responding to a
public records request.
      (2)   The village will provide "prompt" production of records for
inspection, meaning that the records will be produced "without delay" and "with
reasonable speed." Similarly, the village will provide copies of requested
records in a "reasonable period of time." These terms do not mean
"immediately," or "without a moment's delay".
      (3)   The reasonableness of the time taken for each depends on the facts
and circumstances of the particular request. "Prompt" and "reasonable" take
into account time spent on the following response tasks will contribute to the
amount of time it takes to promptly or reasonably respond to requests in a
specific circumstances:
         (a)   Identification of responsive records.
            1.   Clarify or revise request; and
            2.   Identify records.
         (b)   Location and retrieval.
            1.   Locate records and retrieve from storage location, e.g., file
cabinet, branch office, off-site storage facility;
            2.   Volume of records requested; and
            3.   The proximity of the location where the records are stored.
         (c)   Review, analysis, and redaction.
            1.   Examine all materials for possible release;
            2.   Perform necessary legal review and/or consult with
knowledgeable parties;
            3.   Redact exempt materials; and
            4.   Provide explanation and legal authority for all redactions
and/or denials.
         (d)   Preparation.
            1.   Obtain requester's choice of medium; and
            2.   Make copies.
         (e)   Delivery.
            1.   Wait for advance payment of costs; and/or
            2.   Deliver copies or schedule inspection.
   (G)   Routine records requests. Routine requests for records will be
satisfied immediately (if it is feasible to do so). Routine requests include,
but are not limited to, meeting minutes, budgets, salary information, forms and
applications, personnel rosters, etc. If fewer than 20 pages of copies are
requested, or if the records are readily available in an electronic format that
can be e-mailed or downloaded easily, these will be made as quickly as the
equipment allows. If more copies are requested, arrangements should be made
with the requester regarding when the copies or computer files can be picked up
or sent to the requester.
   (H)   Non-routine record requests. In the case of "non-routine requests",
such as those seeking a voluminous number of copies or requiring extensive
research, an acknowledgment of the request shall be given, in a reasonable
period of time, which will include the following:
      (1)   An estimated number of business days it will take to satisfy the
request;
      (2)   An estimated cost if copies are requested; and
      (3)   Any items within the request that may be exempt from disclosure.
   (I)   Denials and redactions. Any denial of public records requested will
include an explanation, including the legal authority justifying the denial. If
portions of a record are public and portions are exempt, the exempt portions
will be redacted and the remainder released. If there are redactions, each
redaction will be accompanied by a supporting explanation, including the legal
authority justifying the redaction.
   (J)   Costs for copies of public records.
      (1)   Those seeking public records will be charged only the actual cost
of making copies or furnishing compact discs. The charge for paper copies will
be $.05 per each page.
      (2)   There will be no charge for documents that are able to be e-mailed.
   (K)   Records request application forms and response forms.
      (1)   No particular records request application form will be required;
any written request that identifies the requestor and reasonably describes the
records or information requested shall be treated as a request that is to be
responded to hereunder. A sample form that will be available at Village Hall
that may be used by a public records requester is attached to Resolution 2021-
6.
      (2)   All requests for public records will be responded to in writing,
with a cover letter or email generally describing the nature of the records
provided, and identifying those that are not provided either because they don't
exist or because they are covered under an exception of the Ohio Revised Code
that exempts them from disclosure.
(Ord. 10-2007, passed 12-3-07; Am. Res. 2021-6, passed 7-22-21)
§ 30.06 IDENTITY THEFT POLICY.
   (A)   Background. The risk to the municipality, its employees and customers
from data loss and identity theft is of significant concern to the municipality
and can be reduced only through the combined efforts of every employee and
contractor.
   (B)   Purpose.
      (1)   The municipality adopts this sensitive information policy to help
protect employees, customers, contractors and the municipality from damages
related to the loss or misuse of sensitive information.
      (2)   This policy will:
         (a)   Define sensitive information;
         (b)   Describe the physical security of data when it is printed on
paper;
         (c)   Describe the electronic security of data when stored and
distributed; and
         (d)   Place the municipality in compliance with state and federal law
regarding identity theft protection.
      (3)   This policy enables the municipality to protect existing customers,
reducing risk from identity fraud, and minimize potential damage to the
municipality from fraudulent new accounts. The program will help the
municipality:
         (a)   Identify risks that signify potentially fraudulent activity
within new or existing covered accounts;
         (b)   Detect risks when they occur in covered accounts;
         (c)   Respond to risks to determine if fraudulent activity has
occurred and act if fraud has been attempted or committed; and
         (d)   Update the program periodically, including reviewing the
accounts that are covered and the identified risks that are part of the
program.
   (C)   Scope. This policy and protection program applies to employees,
contractors, consultants, temporary workers, and other workers at the
municipality, including all personnel affiliated with third parties.
   (D)   Policy. Sensitive Information Policy.
      (1)   Definition of Sensitive Information. Sensitive information includes
the following items whether stored in electronic or printed format:
         (a)   Credit card information, including any of the following:
            1.   Credit card number (in part or whole);
            2.   Credit card expiration date;
            3.   Cardholder name;
            4.   Cardholder address.
         (b)   Tax identification numbers, including:
            1.   Social Security number;
            2.   Business identification number;
            3.   Employer identification numbers;
         (c)   Payroll information, including, among other information:
            1.   Paychecks;
            2.   Pay stubs.
         (d)   Cafeteria plan check requests and associated paperwork.
         (e)   Medical information for any employee or customer, including but
not limited to:
            1.   Doctor names and claims;
            2.   Insurance claims;
            3.   Prescriptions;
            4.   Any related personal medical information;
         (f)   Other personal information belonging to any customer, employee
or contractor, examples of which include:
            1.   Date of birth;
            2.   Address;
            3.   Phone numbers;
            4.   Maiden name;
            5.   Names;
            6.   Customer number;
         (g)   Municipal personnel are encouraged to use common sense judgment
in securing confidential information to the proper extent. Furthermore, this
section should be read in conjunction with the Ohio Public Records Act and the
municipality's open records policy. If an employee is uncertain of the
sensitivity of a particular piece of information, he or she should contact
their supervisor. In the event that the municipality cannot resolve a conflict
between this policy and the Ohio Public Records Act, the municipality will
contact the Ohio Office of Open Records.
      (2)   Hard Copy Distribution. Each employee and contractor performing
work for the municipality will comply with the following policies:
         (a)   File cabinets, desk drawers, overhead cabinets, and any other
storage space containing documents with sensitive information will be locked
when not in use.
         (b)   Storage rooms containing documents with sensitive information
and record retention areas will be locked at the end of each workday or when
unsupervised.
         (c)   Desks, workstations, work areas, printers and fax machines, and
common shared work areas will be cleared of all documents containing sensitive
information when not in use.
         (d)   Whiteboards, dry-erase boards, writing tablets, etc. in common
shared work areas will be erased, removed, or shredded when not in use.
         (e)   When documents containing sensitive information are discarded
they will be placed inside a locked shred bin or immediately shredded using a
mechanical cross cut or Department of Defense (DOD)-approved shredding device.
Locked shred bins are labeled "Confidential paper shredding and recycling."
Municipal records, however, may only be destroyed in accordance with the city's
records retention policy.
      (3)   Electronic Distribution. Each employee and contractor performing
work for the municipality will comply with the following policies:
         (a)   Internally, sensitive information may be transmitted using
approved municipal e-mail. All sensitive information must be encrypted when
stored in an electronic format.
         (b)   Any sensitive information sent externally must be encrypted and
password protected and only to approved recipients. Additionally, a statement
such as this should be included in the e-mail:
"This message may contain confidential and/or proprietary information and is
intended for the person/entity to whom it was originally addressed. Any use by
others is strictly prohibited."
   (E)   Additional identity theft prevention program. If the municipality
maintains certain covered accounts pursuant to federal legislation, the
municipality may include the additional program details.
      (1)   Covered accounts. A covered account includes any account that
involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions. Every new
and existing customer account that meets the following criteria is covered by
this program:
         (a)   Business, personal and household accounts for which there is a
reasonably foreseeable risk of identity theft; or
         (b)   Business, personal and household accounts for which there is a
reasonably foreseeable risk to the safety or soundness of the municipality from
identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or
litigation risks.
      (2)   Red flags.
         (a)   The following red flags are potential indicators of fraud. Any
time a red flag, or a situation closely resembling a red flag, is apparent, it
should be investigated for verification.
            1.   Alerts, notifications or warnings from a consumer reporting
agency;
            2.   A fraud or active duty alert included with a consumer report;
            3.   A notice of credit freeze from a consumer reporting agency in
response to a request for a consumer report; or
            4.   A notice of address discrepancy from a consumer reporting
agency as defined in § 334.82(b) of the Fairness and Accuracy in Credit
Transactions Act.
         (b)   Red flags also include consumer reports that indicate a pattern
of activity inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an
applicant or customer, such as:
            1.   A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries;
            2.   An unusual number of recently established credit
relationships;
            3.   A material change in the use of credit, especially with
respect to recently established credit relationships; or
            4.   An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse
of account privileges by a financial institution or creditor.
      (3)   Suspicious documents.
         (a)   Documents provided for identification that appear to have been
altered or forged;
         (b)   The photograph or physical description on the identification is
not consistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer presenting the
identification;
         (c)   Other information on the identification is not consistent with
information provided by the person opening a new covered account or customer
presenting the identification.
         (d)   Other information on the identification is not consistent with
readily accessible information that is on file with the municipality, such as a
signature card or a recent check.
         (e)   An application appears to have been altered or forged, or gives
the appearance of having been destroyed and reassembled.
      (4)   Suspicious personal identifying information.
         (a)   Personal identifying information provided is inconsistent when
compared against external information sources used by the municipality. For
example:
            1.   The address does not match any address in the consumer report;
            2.   The Social Security number (SSN) has not been issued or is
listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File; or
            3.   Personal identifying information provided by the customer is
not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the
customer. For example, there is a lack of correlation between the SSN range and
date of birth.
         (b)   Personal identifying information provided is associated with
known fraudulent activity as indicated by internal or third-party sources used
by the municipality. For example, the address on an application is the same as
the address provided on a fraudulent application.
         (c)   Personal identifying information provided is of a type commonly
associated with fraudulent activity as indicated by internal or third-party
sources used by the municipality. For example:
            1.   The address on an application is fictitious, a mail drop, or a
prison; or
            2.   The phone number is invalid or is associated with a pager or
answering service.
         (d)   The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other persons
opening an account or other customers.
         (e)   The address or telephone number provided is the same as or
similar to the address or telephone number submitted by an unusually large
number of other customers or other persons opening accounts.
         (f)   The customer or the person opening the covered account fails to
provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in
response to notification that the application is incomplete.
         (g)   Personal identifying information provided is not consistent with
personal identifying information that is on file with the municipality.
         (h)   When using security questions (mother's maiden name, pet's name,
etc.), the person opening the covered account or the customer cannot provide
authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from
a wallet or consumer report.
      (5)   Unusual use of, or suspicious activity related to, the covered
account.
         (a)   Shortly following the notice of a change of address for a
covered account, the municipality receives a request for new, additional, or
replacement goods or services, or for the addition of authorized users on the
account.
         (b)   A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly
associated with known patterns of fraud patterns. For example, the customer
fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent
payments.
         (c)   A covered account is used in a manner that is not consistent
with established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example:
            1.   Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed
payments;
            2.   A material change in purchasing or usage patterns.
         (d)   A covered account that has been inactive for a reasonably
lengthy period of time is used (taking into consideration the type of account,
the expected pattern of usage and other relevant factors).
         (e)   Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as
undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with
the customer's covered account.
         (f)   The municipality is notified that the customer is not receiving
paper account statements.
         (g)   The municipality is notified of unauthorized charges or
transactions in connection with a customer's covered account.
         (h)   The municipality receives notice from customers, victims of
identity theft, law enforcement authorities, or other persons regarding
possible identity theft in connection with covered accounts held by the
municipality.
         (i)   The municipality is notified by a customer, a victim of identity
theft, a law enforcement authority, or any other person that it has opened a
fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft.
   (F)   Responding to red flags.
      (1)   Once potentially fraudulent activity is detected, an employee must
act quickly as a rapid appropriate response can protect customers and the
municipality from damages and loss.
         (a)   Once potentially fraudulent activity is detected, gather all
related documentation and write a description of the situation. Present this
information to the designated authority for determination.
         (b)   The designated authority will complete additional authentication
to determine whether the attempted transaction was fraudulent or authentic.
      (2)   If a transaction is determined to be fraudulent, appropriate
actions must be taken immediately. Actions may include:
         (a)   Canceling the transaction;
         (b)   Notifying and cooperating with appropriate law enforcement;
         (c)   Determining the extent of liability of the municipality; and
         (d)   Notifying the actual customer that fraud has been attempted.
   (G)   Periodic updates to plan.
      (1)   At periodic intervals established in the program, or as required,
the program will be re-evaluated to determine whether all aspects of the
program are up to date and applicable in the current business environment.
      (2)   Periodic reviews will include an assessment of which accounts are
covered by the program.
      (3)   As part of the review, red flags may be revised, replaced or
eliminated. Defining new red flags may also be appropriate.
      (4)   Actions to take in the event that fraudulent activity is discovered
may also require revision to reduce damage to the municipality and its
customers.
   (H)   Program administration.
      (1)   Involvement of management.
         (a)   The Identity Theft Prevention Program shall not be operated as
an extension to existing fraud prevention programs, and its importance warrants
the highest level of attention.
         (b)   The Identity Theft Prevention Program is the responsibility of
the governing body. Approval of the initial plan must be appropriately
documented and maintained.
         (c)   Operational responsibility of the program is delegated to the
Clerk-Treasurer.
      (2)   Staff training.
         (a)   Staff training shall be conducted for all employees, officials
and contractors for whom it is reasonably foreseeable that they may come into
contact with accounts or personally identifiable information that may
constitute a risk to the municipality or its customers.
         (b)   The Clerk-Treasurer is responsible for ensuring identity theft
training for all requisite employees and contractors.
         (c)   Employees must receive annual training in all elements of this
policy.
         (d)   To ensure maximum effectiveness, employees may continue to
receive additional training as changes to the program are made.
      (3)   Oversight of service provider arrangements.
         (a)   It is the responsibility of the municipality to ensure that the
activities of all service providers are conducted in accordance with reasonable
policies and procedures designed to detect, prevent, and mitigate the risk of
identity theft.
         (b)   A service provider that maintains its own identity theft
prevention program, consistent with the guidance of the red flag rules and
validated by appropriate due diligence, may be considered to be meeting these
requirements.
         (c)   Any specific requirements should be specifically addressed in
the appropriate contract arrangements.
(Res. 2008-6, passed 10-20-08)
§ 30.07 DISMISSAL OF TAX DELINQUENCY.
   (A)   The village, at its discretion, may dismiss a tax delinquency claim
filed against a citizen in the Massillon Municipal Court with prejudice so long
as the amount due and owed as alleged in the complaint, along with all court
costs, is paid in full to the village prior to the initial court hearing.
   (B)   The village, at its discretion, may dismiss a tax delinquency claim
filed against a citizen in Massillon Municipal Court without prejudice so long
as the amount due and owed in the complaint, along with all court costs, is
subject to an approved payment plan. If said approved payment plan is not
followed, however, the village may reopen the tax delinquency claim against the
citizen in the Massillon Municipal Court.
(Ord. 3-2012, passed 5-21-12)

§ 31.24 MERGER OF OFFICES.
(Editor's note: Effective January 1, 2023, any references to Clerk-Treasurer
throughout this Title XVII shall now refer to the Village Fiscal Officer)
   Effective January 1, 2023, the duties of Village Clerk and Village Treasurer
shall be combined into the appointed office of a Village Fiscal Officer,
pursuant to R.C. § 733.262. The Village Fiscal Officer may thereafter be
appointed by the Mayor, with approval from a majority of Village Council. Said
Fiscal Officer need not be a resident of the Village of Navarre at the time of
appointment, but shall become a resident of the village within six months after
the effective date of the appointment, unless Village Council, by further
ordinance, waives that requirement.
(Ord. 15-1973, passed 9-18-73; Am. Res. 2023-2, passed 1-9-23)
§ 31.25 SECRETARY TO THE CLERK-TREASURER.
   There is hereby established the position of secretary to the clerk-treasurer
of the village. The secretary shall be hired initially for a six-month
probationary period, subject to final appointment. Appointment shall be made by
the mayor with the advice and consent of council.
(Ord. 12-1972, passed 4-18-72)

   Secretary to clerk-treasurer as secretary to the Village Administrator, §
37.11
§ 31.26 DUTIES OF THE CLERK-TREASURER REGARDING FLOOD AND MUDSLIDE HAZARDS.
   Council will enact as necessary and maintain in force for those areas having
flood hazards, adequate land use and control measures with effective
enforcement provisions consistent with the criteria set forth in Section 1910
of the National Flood Insurance Program Regulations.
   (A)   The clerk-treasurer shall have the responsibility, authority and means
to:
      (1)   Delineate or assist the administrator, at his request, in
delineating the limits of the areas having special flood hazards on
available local maps of sufficient scale to identify the location of building
sites.
      (2)   Provide such information as the administrator may request
concerning present uses and occupancy of the flood plain.
      (3)   Cooperate with federal, state and local agencies and private firms
which undertake to study, survey, map, and identify flood plain or mudslide
areas and cooperate with neighboring communities with respect to management of
adjoining flood plain areas in order to prevent aggravation of existing
hazards.
      (4)   Submit, on the anniversary date of the village's initial
eligibility, an annual report to the administrator on the progress made during
the past year within the village in the development and implementation of flood
plain management measures.
   (B)   The clerk-treasurer shall maintain for public inspection and furnish
upon request, a record of elevations in relation to mean sea level of the
lowest floor, including the basements of all new or substantially improved
structures located in the special flood hazard areas. If the lowest floor is
below grade on one or more sides, the elevation of the floor immediately above
must also be recorded.
   (C)   The clerk-treasurer shall take such other official action as may be
reasonably necessary to carry out the objectives of the program.
(Ord. 16-1974, passed 11-19-74)
Cross-reference:
   Flood control prevention,
Ch. 152
§ 31.50 LEGAL COUNSEL.
   (A)   The village's legal counsel shall be known and referred to as the
Village Solicitor. The Village Solicitor shall an Ohio licensed attorney, in
good standing, and shall be appointed by the Mayor, with advice and consent of
Village Council.
   (B)   The Village Solicitor shall act as attorney and counsel for the
village and the officers thereof in their official capacity, and, as such
attorney, to prosecute and defend all actions by or against the village or any
department or officer thereof during the term of the Village Solicitor's
employment; and render legal opinions to the Village Council, the Mayor, and
the village's departments and officers upon request. The Village Solicitor
shall be employed pursuant to a contract approved by the Mayor and a majority
of the Village Council, said contract not to exceed two years, unless extended
by the Mayor with the advice and consent of Village Council.
(Ord. 20-1983, passed 12-6-83; Am. Ord. 12-2017, passed 7-17-17)

   (A)   The mayor is hereby authorized to establish the position of working
street superintendent and to make an appointment therefor with the consent of
council.
   (B)   The working street superintendent shall not be removed from his
position by the mayor without the consent of two-thirds of all the elected
members of council.

§ 31.53 RECREATION DIRECTOR.
   (A)   Establishment. The position of recreation director is hereby
established. The director shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of
council. (Ord. 8-66, passed 4-21-86)
   (B)   Powers and duties; recreation program.
      (1)   The director shall direct the recreation program with the aid of
assistants for a period of approximately ten to 12 weeks during summer school
vacation.
      (2)   The hours of supervised recreation shall be those agreed upon by
the director and council.
      (3)   The director is hereby authorized to employ not more than eighteen
assistants to assist in the supervision of recreation.
      (4)   The recreation program is hereby authorized pending its success and
may be terminated by council at any time that council feels it is not
fulfilling the needs of the community.
(Ord. 9-67, passed 6-9-67)
Cross-reference:
   Park regulations,
Ch. 96
§ 31.54 ZONING INSPECTOR.
   (A)   There is hereby established the position of zoning inspector for the
village. The zoning inspector shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice
and consent of council.
   (B)   The term of office of the zoning inspector shall be for a period of
one year from the date of appointment.
(Ord. 909, passed 4-7-64)
Cross-reference:
   Flood control, administration by zoning inspector, § 151.65, 152.16
   Powers and duties of the zoning inspector, § 151.60 through 151.70
§ 31.55 WATER/WASTEWATER SUPERINTENDENT.
   (A)   There is hereby created the village employment position of combination
water/wastewater superintendent.
   (B)   In order to qualify for this position, a person must hold all
operator's licenses which are required by the state to operate the village
water and wastewater treatment plants, as the same are now or may hereafter be
required.
   (C)   In order to continue to qualify for this position a person must obtain
all operator's licenses which may be required in the future by the state or any
other governmental entity or agency to operate the village water and wastewater
treatment plants, as they are now or may hereafter be constructed or situated.
(Ord. 17-1979, passed 7-17-79)
§ 31.56 ASSISTANT WITH LICENSE TO WATER/SEWER OPERATOR.
   There is hereby established the position of assistant with license to the
water/sewer operator as a regular employment position for the village.
(Ord. 11-1979, passed 7-3-79)
§ 31.57 VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR.
   (A)   In accordance with R.C. § 735.271, there is hereby created the
position of Village Administrator. The salary of the Village Administrator
shall be $3,600 per year, payable, less usual and customary deductions, in
increments, from time to time, as determined by the usual and customary
disbursements for salary as provided for by the Clerk-Treasurer of the Village.
   (B)   The Village Administrator shall have those powers, duties, and
functions as provided by the laws of the state, and in addition said
Administrator shall have those powers and duties enumerated in R.C. § 735.273.
   (C)   The Village Administrator is hereby designated as the purchasing agent
for all village offices, departments, divisions, boards, and commissions and
said Administrator shall make all contracts, purchase supplies or materials,
and provide for any work of the village in the manner provided by R.C. §
731.141.
   (D)   The Village Administrator is hereby authorized to promulgate written
rules and procedures to be followed by all village officers and employees
relative to the requisitioning of supplies, materials, and work for their
respective offices, departments, divisions, boards or commissions. Such rules
and procedures shall not conflict with any of the provisions of the ordinances
of the village.
(Ord. 19-1997, passed 1-12-98)
LEGISLATIVE
   
*32.09   Meetings
   
32.12   Ordinances
*EDITOR'S NOTE
   This section contains municipal ordinances which supercede the Ohio Basic
Code section of the same number.
§ 32.09 MEETINGS.
   (A)   Council shall, except as otherwise provided in this section, meet in
regular session at the council chambers, located at 27 West Canal St., Navarre,
Ohio, 44662, at 7:30 p.m. on the first and third Mondays of each month. Should
any holiday fall upon the date for a regular meeting, council may appoint
another date within the same month in lieu thereof. Council may also, from time
to time, change the meeting place for either a regular or special meeting. Any
change in the date, time or place of meeting, for a regular meeting, or the
calling of a special meeting shall comply with the meeting notification
provisions for council members and the news media, as provided for herein. The
mayor or any three members may call special meetings upon at least 12 hours
notice to each member, served personally or left at his or her usual place of
residence. When a special meeting is called, the Clerk-Treasurer of the Village
shall give at least 24 hours' advance notice to the news media that have
requested notification, except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate
official action. In the event of an emergency, the Clerk-Treasurer of the
Village shall notify the news media that have requested notification
immediately of the time, place, and purpose of the meeting.
   (B)   The Council further authorizes the Clerk-Treasurer of the Village to
ensure compliance with Chapter 38 of the Codified Ordinances of said Village,
with regard to all regular and special meetings of said Council.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63; Am. Ord. 16-1996, passed 12-3-96; Am. Ord. 3-1998,
passed 2-9-98)
Cross-reference:
   Notification of public meetings, Ch. 37
Statutory reference:
   Open meetings, R.C. § 121.22
§ 32.12 ORDINANCES.
   (A)   Adoption of ordinances. Each measure of a general nature hereafter
adopted, other than an ordinance of general application limited to a single
occasion, wherever practicable, shall be of a form re-enacting, revising,
supplementing or amending an appropriate title, chapter or section of this
code. The ordinance, when so adopted, shall become part of this code as though
included in their original enactment, and shall constitute a repealer of any
previous section or sections intended to be repealed thereby. The provisions of
this division and divisions (B) and (C) below are directory and failure of
council to comply therewith shall not affect the validity of any ordinance.
   (B)   Numbering of sections. Each measure enacted as provided in division
(A) above shall be assigned an appropriate caption and section number.
   (C)   Correction of form of ordinances. It shall be the duty of the clerk-
treasurer and o£ the solicitor, or either, whenever the form of a proposed
measure does not comply with the provisions of the preceding sections, to call
the attention of council thereto, and the solicitor shall submit a draft of the
measure which, if adopted, will correct the omission.
   (D)   Publication. Each ordinance of a general nature hereafter adopted
shall be published in the manner provided by law.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
POLICE DEPARTMENT
   
*34.03   Appointment of deputies and police officers; examination; age limits

*EDITOR'S NOTE
   This section contains municipal ordinances which supercede the Ohio Basic
Code section of the same number.
§ 34.03 APPOINTMENT OF DEPUTIES AND POLICE OFFICERS; EXAMINATION; AGE LIMITS.
   (A)   The mayor shall, when provided for by the council, and subject to its
confirmation, appoint all deputies, police officers, night watchmen, and
special police officers. All officers shall continue in office until removed
therefrom for the cause and in the manner provided by R.C. § 737.19.
   (B)   No person shall receive an appointment under this section unless he
has, not more than 60 days prior to receiving appointment, passed a physical
examination given by a licensed physician, showing that he meets the physical
requirements necessary to perform the duties of the position to which he is to
be appointed as established by the council. The appointing authority shall,
prior to making any appointment, file with the police and firemen's disability
and pension fund a copy of the report or findings of the licensed physician.
The professional fee for such physical examination shall be paid for by the
council. (R.C. § 737.16)
   (C)   Members of the police department shall be not less than 21 nor more
than 65 years of age and able-bodied. Candidates shall pass a satisfactory
mental and physical examination before becoming members of the department.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
§ 34.04 AUXILIARY POLICE UNITS.
   (A)   There is hereby established an auxiliary police unit for the village.
   (B)   The members of the auxiliary police unit shall be appointed by the
mayor with the advice and consent of council.
   (C)   The term of service of auxiliary police officers shall be a period of
time not to exceed one year in length and those officers may be removed at any
time at the discretion of the mayor.
   (D)   The members of the unit shall be not less than 21 years of age at the
time of their appointment, nor more than 65 years of age during the term of
their office as auxiliary police officers. Any auxiliary police officer
reaching the age of 65 years during his term of office shall automatically be
removed from the unit.
   (E)   The members of the unit shall have not less than a high school diploma
to qualify for appointment thereto.
   (F)   The mayor shall be the commanding officer of the unit and shall have
control of the assignment, training, stationing, and direction of work of the
unit. The unit shall have all police powers but shall perform only such police
duties as are assigned by the mayor and shall act only when in the prescribed
uniform or portion of uniform. The mayor shall prescribe the time and place the
uniform or portion thereof is to be worn. Unit members shall obey the chain of
command of the police department, and shall take orders from all regularly
appointed members thereof.
   (G)   All auxiliary police officers shall have a physical examination every
five years as a requirement of their appointment.
   (H)   All candidates for membership in the unit shall take a written and
oral examination as prescribed by the mayor and must score a passing grade
thereon as a requirement for appointment to the unit.
   (I)   All auxiliary police officers shall be trained without compensation
and at the convenience of the regular police department. The chief of police
shall supervise all training of auxiliary unit members. Training shall include
instruction on the general duties of police officers, civil defense procedures,
emergency fire-fighting procedures and controls, and, as a minimum, a basic
course in first aid as set forth by the American Red Cross.
   (J)   Each unit member shall furnish himself with a night stick and uniform
as approved by the mayor, and with any other equipment which is deemed
necessary, except a badge, which will be furnished by the village and will
remain the property of the village. No member of the auxiliary unit shall carry
any firearm except as directed by the mayor. Abuse of this prohibition shall be
considered grounds for immediate dismissal from the unit.
   (K)   All members of the unit shall be called to duty only by the mayor and
the compensation for active duty shall be as established from time to time by
council, such funds to be taken from the "other expenses" of the police safety
fund of the budget.
   (L)   The mayor shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the
organization, administration, conduct, and control of the unit.
(Ord. 923, passed 8-18-64; Am. Ord. 8-1979, passed 4-17-79)
 Statutory reference:
   Auxiliary police units, see R.C. § 737.161
§ 34.13 CAPTAIN OF THE VILLAGE POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   There is hereby created the position of captain of the village police
department.
   (B)   The mayor may, subject to confirmation by the legislative authority of
the village, appoint a person as captain. As a prerequisite to appointment,
that person must be a full-time officer of the village police department.
   (C)   No one, except a full-time officer of the village police department
shall hold or continue to hold the position of captain.
   (D)   The captain shall have no duties other than his duties as a full-time
officer of the village police department, except as provided for herein.
      (1)   The sole duty of captain shall be to act as chief of police when
called to do so, and in the sole discretion of, the mayor.
      (2)   When acting as chief, the captain shall continue to perform all of
his duties as a full-time officer.
      (3)   The captain shall cease acting as chief when instructed to do so,
and in the sole discretion of, the mayor.
   (E)   Any appointment as captain shall be made subject to the provisions of
R.C. § 737.17.
(Ord. 17-1980, passed 11-18-80)
§ 34.20 UNIFORM ALLOWANCE; STANDARD UNIFORMS.
   (A)   The clothing or uniform allowance for full-time members of the village
police department is hereby set at the rate of $1,000 per year.
   (B)   The clothing or uniform allowance for auxiliary members of the village
police department is hereby set at the rate of $350 per year.
   (C)   Both full-time and auxiliary members of the police department may
accumulate this allowance, but only to a maximum of $75 full-time, and $25
auxiliary, which shall not include the current year's allowance.
   (D)   All purchases for which an allowance is requested are subject to the
prior approval of the chief of the village police department, who shall, in his
sole discretion, grant or deny a request to apply all or a portion of a request
to utilize this allowance or accumulation thereof.
   (E)   The police chief shall be guided in his decision based upon the
standard uniform, which normally includes:
      (1)   Black shoes.
      (2)   Gray trousers, with black strips along the side.
      (3)   Gray shirt, with black flaps and shoulder straps.
      (4)   Black, lightweight windbreaker jacket.
      (5)   Winter; black short jacket.
      (6)   Gray, spring and fall jacket.
      (7)   Tie.
      (8)   Short-sleeve, summer shirt.
      (9)   Standard leather goods.
   (F)   The objective of the police chief shall be, insofar as this is
possible, to maintain a regular and uniform appearance for both the full-time
and auxiliary members of the department. To this end, the police chief may
require that both full-time and auxiliary members of the department purchase
appropriate clothing or other accessories, utilizing the clothing or uniform
allowance when a full-time or auxiliary member's uniform is shabby, torn, or
otherwise inappropriate for duty.
(Ord. 14-1981, passed 5-19-81; Am. Ord. 3-1984, passed 3-20-84; Am. Ord. 10-
1985, passed 10-1-85; Am. Ord. 2-1994, passed 5-3-94; Am. Ord. 02-2015, passed
2-2-15)
§ 34.21 LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer of the village is hereby authorized to create Fund
Number B11-F-161, which will constitute the Law Enforcement Trust Fund, as is
required by and funded with proceeds and forfeited moneys, in accordance with
sections 2923.32, 2923.35, 2925.03, 2925.42, 2933.41, and 2933.43 of the Ohio
Revised Code.
   (B)   Moneys from said Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall not be used to meet
the general operating costs of the Village Police Department that are
historically funded by the village.
   (C)   Moneys from said Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall be expended only in
accordance with the written Internal Control Policy adopted by the Chief of the
Village Police Department, to:
      (1)   Pay the costs of protracted or complex investigations or
prosecutions;
      (2)   Provide reasonable technical training or expertise;
      (3)   Provide matching funds to obtain federal grants to aid law
enforcement;
      (4)   Support DARE programs or other community preventive education
programs designed to educate adults or children with respect to the dangers
associated with the use of drugs of abuse;
      (5)   Support such other programs and other law enforcement purposes that
the Village Council shall, from time to time, determine to be appropriate.
      (6)   At least 10% of the first $100,000 of proceeds and forfeited
moneys, and at least 20% of the proceeds and forfeited moneys exceeding
$100,000 that are deposited in the Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall be used in
connection wish community preventive education programs.
      (7)   All financial records of the receipts of these proceeds and
forfeited moneys, the general types of expenditures made out of these moneys,
and the specific amount of each general type of expenditure by any village
agency from the Law Enforcement Trust Fund, and all annual reports provided for
hereunder are public records open for inspection under section 149.43 of the
Revised Code; provided, however, that specific expenditures shall not be
immediately disclosed during ongoing investigations if the Chief of the Village
Police Department determines that such disclosure could compromise the
investigation, or said section 149.43 of the Revised Code otherwise exempts
such disclosure.
   (D)   The Chief of the Village Police Department shall keep a log of all
moneys and forfeited proceeds from the sale of forfeited assets that are
received and the log shall include the date and amount of such funds that are
received.
   (E)   The Chief of the Village Police Department shall keep a log of all
expenditures from the Law Enforcement Trust Fund, documenting the date, amount,
and use of each expenditure.
   (F)   The Chief of the Village Police Department shall keep a log of all
property seized for forfeiture which shall be properly itemized and recorded in
accordance with the procedures of the Department.
   (G)   The Chief of the Village Police Department shall file an annual report
with the Village Council, no later than January 31 of each next calendar year,
for the preceding calendar year, verifying that the proceeds and forfeited
moneys from said Law Enforcement Trust Fund were used only for the purposes
authorized herein, and specifying the amounts expended for each authorized
purpose.
   (H)   The Chief of the Village Police Department shall further file the
report provided for in division (G) of this section, with the Ohio Attorney
General, not later than March 1 of each next calendar year.
(Ord. 2-1997, passed 1-8-97)
§ 34.22 INSPECTION OF UNDER SPEED VEHICLES.
   (A)   The Police Department shall perform inspections of under speed
vehicles that comply with inspection requirements established by the Ohio
Department of Public Safety (DPS-1373), at the Department's estimated actual
cost (currently $40), and is authorized to perform inspections of similar
vehicles for non-village residents for $75 per inspection. For the purpose of
this section, "under speed vehicle" means a three- or four-wheeled vehicle,
including a vehicle commonly known as a golf cart, with an attainable speed on
a paved level surface of not more than 20 miles per hour and with a gross
vehicle weight rating less than 3,000 pounds as set forth in R.C. § 4501.0J
(XX).
   (B)   At the time of inspection, the owner/operator of the under speed
vehicle must present the following to the Navarre Police Department: (i) a
valid driver's license; (ii) proof of insurance relating to use of the under
speed vehicle; (iii) proof of registration; and (iv) gross vehicle weight. The
Navarre Police Department shall have the right to not issue an inspection
certificate to any applicant for any or no reason.
   (C)   Inspection fees, though to be paid to the Village Fiscal Officer,
shall be for the benefit of the Police Department, and the amounts so collected
shall be added to the appropriation for the Police Department for uses deemed
necessary by the Police Chief, with approval of the Mayor.
(Ord. 1-2022, passed 2-7-22)

§ 35.01 MUNICIPAL FIRE REGULATIONS; ESTABLISHMENT, COMPOSITION OF FIRE
DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   The council may establish all necessary regulations to guard against
the occurrence of fires and protect the property and lives of its citizens
against damage and accidents resulting therefrom, and for that purpose may
establish and maintain a fire department, provide for the establishment and
organization of fire engine and hose companies and rescue units, establish the
hours of labor of the members of its fire department who shall not be required
to be on duty continuously more than 6 days in every 7, and provide bylaws and
regulation for the government of companies and their members as is necessary
and proper. (R.C. § 737.21)
   (B)   There is hereby created in and for the village fire department, to be
composed of a fire chief and such other officers and personnel as council shall
from time to time determine. ('75 Code, § 248.01)

§ 35.14 CONTRACTS FOR FIRE PROTECTION.
   The mayor and the clerk-treasurer are hereby authorized to enter into a
contract with any municipality, political subdivision, corporation, individual,
or groups of individuals, for a period not to exceed two years, which may be
renewed for succeeding periods not to exceed two years, whereby the village and
its inhabitants shall be furnished all necessary fire protection. The contract
shall provide for compensation based upon any of the provisions of R.C. § 9.60.
(Ord. 562, passed 2-19-46)
§ 35.20 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (A)   There is hereby created an emergency ambulance service for the
residents of the village.
   (B)   The service is to be operated by the village fire department, with
personnel especially trained and qualified as emergency ambulance technicians,
or at least the equivalent thereof.
   (C)   The service is to be provided for the residents of the village and
visitors to the village.

passed 3-20-79)
§ 35.21 OVERSIGHT BY COUNCIL.

council, from time to time, concerning the utilization of this service, and the
expense involved.
   (B)   The council of the village is hereby authorized to appropriate the
necessary funds for the operation and maintenance of the service, including,
but not limited to the purchase of equipment and vehicles.
(Ord. 20-1978, passed 10-3-78; Am. Ord. 3-1979, passed 2-6-79; Am. Ord. 7-1979,
passed 3-20-79)
§ 35.22 STANDARDS OF PERFORMANCE.
   (A)   The fire department shall comply with all applicable federal and state
laws and regulations concerning the operation of the service and shall
immediately notify the mayor of the village concerning any violations thereof.
   (B)   It is understood that the operation of this service shall in no way
jeopardize the fire-fighting capabilities of the fire department.
(Ord. 20-1978, passed 10-3-78; Am. Ord. 3-1979, passed 2-6-79; Am. Ord. 7-1979,

37.02.

§ 37.02 FEES.
   (A)   Sale of lots. Lots shall be sold by the board of cemetery trustees for
the sum of $300 to residents of the village, and $500 for non-residents of the
village. However, non-resident employees of the village, who have been
continuously employed for a minimum period of five years shall be entitled to
purchase a maximum of two lots at the same price as that offered to residents
of the village. All prices are per lot.
(Ord. 23-1973, passed 12-18-73; Am. Ord. 10-1976, passed 8-3-76; Am. Ord. 15-
1976, passed 11-16-76; Am. Ord. 6-1978, passed 3-7-78; Am. Ord. 10-1980, passed
8-5-80; Am. Ord. 13-1980, passed 9-2-80; Am. Ord. 7-1988, passed 4-19-88; Am.
Ord. 12-1997, passed 8-25-97)
   (B)   Opening and closing of graves. The cost for the opening and closing of
graves in the village cemeteries shall be as follows:
      (1) Vault size up to and including four feet      $ 90
      (2) Vault size over four feet             300
(Am. Ord. 8-1994, passed 7-19-94; Am. Ord. 12-1997, passed 8-25-97)

total cost for the burial of infants in the infant section of the cemeteries
shall be $90 per burial.
   (D)   Tombstone foundation. The minimum cost for a tombstone foundation
shall be $50. Any tombstone foundation of a size in excess of two feet by one
foot shall be charged at the rate of $10 per cubic foot, over and above the
minimum charge.
(Am. Ord. 12-1997, passed 8-25-97)

and closing graves for the purpose of cremation interments shall be in the
amount of $100 per opening and closing. (Am. Ord. 8- 1994, passed 7-19-94)
   (F)   Disinterments. In addition to the fees provided for in division (B)
herein, there shall be a charge of $500 for a disinterment. (Am. Ord. 8-1994,
passed 7-19-94)
   (G)   Additional grave preparation. Any additional grave preparation not
specified herein shall be charged at the rate of $10 per hour, with a minimum
charge of $20 per interment. (Am. Ord. 8-1994, passed 7-19-94)
   (H)   Saturday grave preparation. There shall be an additional charge in the
amount of $100 for any Saturday grave or funeral preparation.
   (I)   Grave closing after 4:00 p.m. There shall be an additional charge in
the amount of $100 for any grave closing after 4:00 p.m.
(Am. Ord. 8-1994, passed 7-19-94)
   (J)   Memorial crypt. There shall be an additional charge in the amount of
$1,000 for care and maintenance of a lot or lots with a memorial crypt. Crypts
are to be permitted in #l Cemetery only.
   (K)   Cemetery deed. There shall be a charge in the amount of $10 for each
cemetery deed. (Am. Ord. 8-1994, passed 7-19-94)
   (L)   Cemetery endowment fund. From the sale of each and every lot there
shall be taken the sum of $25 which shall be transferred into the cemetery
endowment fund. This amount of $25 shall be nonrefundable in the event a lot or
lots are returned by a purchaser to the village. (Ord. 14-66, passed 9-6-66;
Am. Ord. 10-1976, passed 8-3-76; Am. Ord. 15-1976, passed 11-16-76; Am. Ord. 6-
1978, passed 3-7-78; Am. Ord.

§ 37.26 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   The terms of the three persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be three
years, except that the term of two of the members appointed to the first shade
tree commission shall be only one and two years respectively. In the event that
a vacancy occurs during the term of any member, his successor shall be
appointed for the unexpired portion of that term.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71)
§ 37.27 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the shade tree commission shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71)
§ 37.28 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The shade tree commission shall have the power to study, investigate, plan,
advise, report and recommend to council, the street commissioner, or the mayor,
any action, program, plan, or legislation which the commission finds or
determines to be necessary or advisable for the care, preservation, trimming,
planting, replanting, removal, or disposition of trees and shrubs in public
ways, streets, and alleys.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71)
§ 37.29 ORGANIZATION; PROCEDURES.
   (A)   The shade tree commission shall choose its own officers, make its own
rules and regulations, and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the
members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. All plans, findings,
advice, reports, and recommendations made by the commission shall be in writing
and designate by name those members of the commission approving or concurring
therein; members who do not so approve or concur therein shall have the right,
as a part of the report, to state their reasons for refusing to approve or
concur.
   (B)   The commission, when requested by council or the mayor, shall
consider, investigate, make findings, report, and recommend upon any special
matter or question coming within the scope of its work.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71)
§ 37.35 ESTABLISHMENT OF BOARD OF REVIEW.
   For provisions regarding the board of review, see § 97.12.
§ 37.40 ESTABLISHMENT OF BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   For provisions regarding the board of zoning appeals, see §§ 151.80 through
151.87.
§ 37.45 ESTABLISHMENT OF PLANNING COMMISSION.
   For provisions regarding the planning commission, see § 51.75.
NOTIFICATION OF PUBLIC MEETINGS
   
38.01   Purpose
   
38.02   Definitions
   
38.03   Notice of regular and organizational meetings
   
38.04   Notice of special meetings
   
38.05   Notice to news media of special meetings
   
38.06   Notification of discussion of specific types of public business
   
38.07   Compliance with rules; duties of the Clerk-Treasurer
§ 38.01 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The council has adopted the following rules for the purposes of:
      (1)   Establishing a reasonable method for any person to determine the
time and place of all regularly scheduled meetings and the time, place, and
purpose of all special meetings.
      (2)   Making provisions for giving advance notice of special meetings to
the news media that have requested notification.
      (3)   Making provisions for persons to request and obtain reasonable
advance notification of all meetings at which any specific type of public
business is to be discussed.
   (B)   These rules apply to each municipal body, as defined in § 38.02 of
this village, and are in addition to any applicable legal requirements as to
notice to members of a municipal body or to others in connection with specific
meetings or specific subject matters.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)
§ 38.02 DEFINITIONS.
   "CLERK-TREASURER." The village clerk-treasurer.
   "DAY." A calendar day.
   "MEETING." Any pre-arranged discussion of the public business of the
municipal body by a majority of the members of that municipal body.
   "MUNICIPAL BODY." Each of the following:
      (1)   Village council.
      (2)   Board of zoning appeals.
      (3)   Planning commission.
      (4)   Village Administrator.
      (5)   Committees of the above-named municipal bodies comprised of members
of those bodies if committees are comprised of a majority of the members of the
main municipal body, or are decision-making committees.
   "ORAL NOTIFICATION." Notification given orally, either in person or by
telephone, directly to the person for whom the notification is intended, or by
leaving an oral message for that person at the address (or if by telephone at
the telephone number) of that person as shown on the records kept by the clerk-
treasurer under these rules.
   "POST." To post in an area accessible to the public during the usual
business hours at the office of the clerk-treasurer, and at the following
locations: post office, Navarre Deposit Bank, J.D. Define Grocery, Alice's
Restaurant, Muskoff's Drug Store. A notice identifying the locations at which
notifications will be posted pursuant to these rules shall be published by the
clerk-treasurer within ten calendar days after the adoption of these rules.
   "PUBLISHED." Published once in a newspaper having general circulation in the
village, as defined in R.C. § 7.12, except that no portion of that newspaper
need be printed in the village. If at the time of any such publication there is
no such newspaper of general circulation, then publication shall be in a
newspaper then determined by the clerk-treasurer to have the largest
circulation in the village.
   "SPECIAL MEETING." A meeting which is neither a regular meeting nor an
adjournment of a regular or special meeting to another time or day to consider
items specifically stated on the original agenda of that regular or special
meeting.
   "WRITTEN NOTIFICATION." Notification, in writing, which is telegraphed or in
any way delivered to the address of the person for whom the notification is
intended as shown on the records kept by the clerk-treasurer under these rules.
If mailed, notification shall be mailed by first-class mail, deposited in a
U.S. postal service mailbox not later than the second day preceding the day of
the meeting to which the notification refers, provided that at least one
regular mail delivery day shall fall between the day of mailing and the day of
the meeting.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)
§ 38.03 NOTICE OF REGULAR AND ORGANIZATIONAL MEETINGS.
   (A)   The clerk-treasurer shall post a statement of the times and places of
regular meetings of each municipal body for each calendar year not later than
the second day preceding the day of the first regular meeting (other than the
organizational meeting) of the calendar year of that municipal body. The clerk-
treasurer shall ensure that the statement remains so posted during the calendar
year. If, at any time during the calendar year the time or place of regular
meetings, or of any regular meeting is changed on a permanent or temporary
basis, a statement of the time and place of such changed regular meetings shall
be posted by the clerk-treasurer at least 24 hours before the time of the first
changed regular meeting.
   (B)   The clerk-treasurer shall post a statement of the time and place of
any organizational meeting of a municipal body at least 24 hours before the
time of the organizational meeting.
   (C)   Upon the adjournment of any regular or special meeting to another day,
the clerk-treasurer shall promptly post notice of the time and place of the
adjourned meeting.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)
§ 38.04 NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (A)   Except in the case of a special meeting referred to in §
38.05(D) of these rules, the clerk-treasurer shall, not later than 24 hours
before the time of a special meeting of a municipal body, post a statement of
the time, place, and purposes of that special meeting.
   (B)   The statement under this section and the notifications under §
38.05 shall state the specific or general purposes then known to the clerk-
treasurer to be intended to be considered at the special meeting and may state,
as an additional purpose, that any other business as may properly come before
the municipal body at the meeting may be considered and acted upon.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)
§ 38.05 NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (A)   News media organizations that desire to be given advance notification
of special meetings of a municipal body shall file with the clerk-treasurer a
written request therefor. Except in the event of an emergency requiring
immediate official action as referred to in division (D) below, a special
meeting shall not be held unless at least 24 hours advance notice of the time,
place, and purposes of the special meeting if given to the news media that have
requested the advance notification in accordance with division (B) below.
   (B)   News media requests for advance notification of special meetings shall
specify: the municipal body that is the subject of the request; the name of the
medium; the name and address of the person to whom written notification to the
medium may be mailed, telegraphed, or delivered; and the names, addresses, and
telephone numbers (including addresses and telephone numbers at which
notification may be given either during or outside of business hours) of at
least two persons, to either of whom oral notification to the medium may be
given. Any such request shall be effective for one year from the date of filing
with the clerk-treasurer, or until the clerk-treasurer receives written notice
from such medium canceling or modifying the request, whichever is earlier. Each
requesting news medium shall be informed of the period of effectiveness at the
time it files its request. Requests may be modified or extended only by filing
a complete new request with the clerk-treasurer. A request shall not be deemed
to be made unless it is complete in all respects, and the request may be
conclusively relied upon by the village, the municipal body that is the subject
of the request, and the clerk-treasurer.
   (C)   The clerk-treasurer shall give oral or written notification to the
news media that have requested the advance notification, in accordance with
division (B), of the time, place and purpose of each special meeting, at least
24 hours prior to the time of the special meeting.
   (D)   In the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting may be held without giving 24 hours advance notification
thereof to the requesting news media, notwithstanding the provisions of
division (C) above. The person calling the meeting, or the clerk-treasurer on
his behalf, shall immediately give oral notification, written notification, or
both of the time, place, and purpose of the special meeting to the news media
that have requested advance notification in accordance with division (B) above.
The minutes, the telephone call, or both, of any such special meeting shall
state the general nature of the emergency requiring immediate official action.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)
§ 38.06 NOTIFICATION OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   (A)   Any person, upon written request and as provided herein, may obtain
reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which any specific type of
public business is scheduled to be discussed. That person may file a written
request with the clerk-treasurer specifying: the person's name; the addresses
and telephone numbers at or through that person can be reached during and
outside of business hours; the specific type of public business the discussion
of which the person is requesting advance notification; the municipal body that
is the subject of the request; and the number of calendar months (not to exceed
three) which the request covers. The request may be canceled by notifying the
clerk-treasurer. Each written request must be accompanied by cash, check, or
money order (payable to the Village of Navarre), in the amount of $1 for each
month covered by the request, which amount has been determined by the council
to represent a reasonable fee to cover costs of providing such advance
notification. No funds paid under this division shall be refunded. Requests may
be modified or extended only by filing a new request with the clerk-treasurer.
A request shall not be deemed to be made unless it is complete in all respects
and such request may be conclusively relied upon by the village, municipal body
that is the subject of the request, and the clerk-treasurer.
   (B)   The clerk-treasurer shall give such advance notification under this
section by written notification, by oral notification, or both, as the clerk-
treasurer determines. The contents of written notification under this division
may be a copy of the agenda of the meeting. Written notification under this
division may be accomplished by giving advance written notification, by copies
of agendas, of all meetings of the municipal body that are within the subject
matter of the request.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)
§ 38.07 COMPLIANCE WITH RULES; DUTIES OF THE CLERK-TREASURER.
   (A)   Any person may visit or telephone the office of the clerk-treasurer
during the officer's regular hours to determine the time and place of regular
meetings; the time, place, and purpose of any then known special meeting; and
whether the available agenda of any such future meeting states that any
specific type of public business is to be discussed at that meeting.
   (B)   Any notification provided herein to be given by the clerk- treasurer
may be given by any person acting on behalf of or under the authority of the
clerk-treasurer.
   (C)   A reasonable attempt at notification shall constitute notification in
compliance with these rules.
   (D)   Any certificate by the clerk-treasurer as to compliance with these
rules shall be deemed conclusive of compliance.
   (E)   The clerk-treasurer shall maintain a record of the date and manner
(and time, if pertinent under these rules) of all actions taken with regard to
notices and notifications under §§ 38.04 through 38.06, and shall retain copies
of proofs of publication of any notifications or notices published thereunder.
(Ord. 7-1976, passed 6-15-76)

§ 39.01 EMPLOYMENT OF MINORS.
   No person under the age of 18 years shall be employed by any agency of the
village government.
(Ord. 15-68, passed 6-18-68)
§ 39.10 BEREAVEMENT PAY.
   In the event that a member of a full-time employee's immediate family dies
(mother, father, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-law, child, spouse,
grandparent) the employee shall be granted up to three days off or until the
day of the funeral, whichever first occurs, with pay. Funeral leave taken
during vacation time shall not be reimbursed, nor shall compensatory time off
be provided.
(Ord. 21-1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 27-1981, passed 12-15-81; Am. Ord. 20-

passed 2-28-22; Am. Ord. 6A-2022, passed 3-21-22)
§ 39.11 JURY DUTY.
   In the event that an employee is called to jury duty, the employee shall be
paid the difference between the pay for jury service and the regular salary or
wage, computed on a per diem basis, upon presentation of written evidence of
said jury service.
(Ord. 21-1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 27-1981, passed 12-15-81; Am. Ord. 20-
