§ 39.12 HOLIDAYS.
   (A)   Holidays, with pay, for all full-time village employees, except full-
time members of the Navarre Village Police Department, shall be as follows: New
Year's Day, President's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Veteran's
Day, Thanksgiving, the Friday immediately following Thanksgiving, Christmas,
the employee's birthday, and two personal days (to be granted with at least one
week's notice to the appropriate superior employee or other village officer who
shall, in his/her discretion, grant or deny a particular request).
   (B)   Full-time members of the Navarre Village Police Department have no
paid holidays but shall be given, instead, a total of 12 non-restricted
personal days to be arranged by the Navarre Village Police Chief, with the
proviso that any unused personal days within a given calendar year shall be
forfeited by said full-time police department member, so as not to accumulate
from year to year.
(Ord. 3-1973, passed 1-2-73; Am. Ord. 1-1979, passed 1-2-79; Am. Ord. 27-1979,
passed 12-4-79; Am. Ord. 21-1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 27-1981, passed 12-
15-81; Am. Ord. 20-1982, passed 12-18-82; Am. Ord. 5-1984, passed 4-17-84; Am.
Ord. 12-1987, passed 7-21-87; Am. Ord. 19-1987, passed 11-17-87; Am. Ord. 15-
1988, passed 7-5-88; Am. Ord. 10-1989, passed 6-20-89; Am. Ord. 5-1990, passed
6-29-90; Am. Ord. 15-1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 6-1992, passed 5-19-92; Am.
Ord. 7- 1992, passed 5-19-1992; Am. Ord. 6-2022, passed 2-28-22; Am. Ord. 6A-
2022, passed 3-21-22)
§ 39.13 VACATIONS.
   (A)   Vacation time, with pay, for all full-time employees provided for by
this section shall be as follows:
   Length of Service               Vacation
   One full year                  One work week
   Two through seven full years            Two work weeks
   Eight through 14 full years            Three work weeks
   15 through 19 full years            Four work weeks
   20 through 25 full years            Five work weeks
   (B)   For lengths of service over 25 years, employees shall receive one
additional day for each full year of service, which shall not exceed a total of
six work weeks of vacation per year. Vacation time, with pay, shall be computed
based either upon the last date of hire or the confirmed total state pension
years of service, whichever provides the longer length of service. Vacation
time cannot be accumulated from year to year and vacation time must be
arranged, in advance, with the appropriate superior employee or officer. In the
event of any emergency, and an employee is called to work during the vacation
period, the employee shall be paid for the vacation time and, in addition,
shall be paid time-and-a-half for each hour worked, or part thereof.
(Ord. 16-1973, passed 10-2-73; Am. Ord. 1-1979, passed 1-2-79; Am. Ord. 27-
1979, passed 12-4-79; Am. Ord. 21-1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 27-1981,
passed 12-15-81; Am. Ord. 20-1982, passed 12-18-82; Am. Ord. 5-1984, passed 4-
17-84; Am. Ord. 12-1987, passed 7-21-87; Am. Ord. 15-1988, passed 7-5-88; Am.
Ord. 10-1989, passed 6-20-89; Am. Ord. 5-1990, passed 6-29-90; Am. Ord. 15-
1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 6-1992, passed 5-19-92; Am. Ord. 7-1992, passed
5-19-1992; Am. Ord. 6-2022, passed 2-28-22; Am. Ord. 6A-2022, passed 3-21-22)
§ 39.14 HOSPITALIZATION.
   (A)   The clerk-treasurer and the mayor are hereby directed and authorized
to enter into a contract to provide hospitalization insurance, including
medical and surgical benefits, for the chief of police, members of the police
department, the cemetery sexton, class A and B employees, the water plant
operator and maintenance man, the sewer plant operator and maintenance man, the
secretary to the clerk- treasurer and the assistants to the water and sewer
plant operators and maintenance men.
(Ord. 8-69, passed 6-26-69)
   (B)   The clerk-treasurer is authorized, upon proper certification of funds,
to pay an amount equal to 13% of the health insurance premium for the village
prosecutor, commencing February 1, 1986, and ending June 15, 1986. (Ord. 20-
1985, passed 12-30-85)
   (C)   The clerk-treasurer shall, commencing January 15, 1988, be included as
an insured under the village's present and future group medical insurance
policy or policies. The cost for this insurance coverage shall be paid for, by
the village, as an addition to the salary of the clerk-treasurer. The
individual or family coverage provided for by this coverage shall be the same
as that available to other employees presently being provided group health
insurance. (Ord. 2-1988, passed 1-8-88)
§ 39.15 PART-TIME EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   "PART-TIME EMPLOYEE" is defined as any person holding a position
subject to appointment, removal, promotion, or reduction by an appointing
officer, board, or the legislative body of this village, who normally works
less than 40 hours per week.
   (B)   No part-time employee is entitled to sick leave benefits of any
nature, kind, or description; past, present, or future.
(Ord. 21-1984, passed 12-18-84)
§ 39.20 COMPUTATION OF OVERTIME.
   (A)   All payments of wages, as provided for herein, whether computed on an
hourly or salary rate, provide for normal, full-time wages only. Any overtime
wages due shall be computed in conformity with the provisions of applicable
state or federal law.
   (B)   For the purpose of computing the first 40 hours per week for overtime
payment calculation requirements, the following items shall be considered in
making this computation:
      (1)   Actual hours worked.
      (2)   Sick leave, which has been granted with sick pay, on a day-to-day
basis.
      (3)   Paid holidays, as provided in § 39.12.
   (C)   Time-and-one-half of the hourly based wage or salary shall be paid to
any full-time village employee for working over eight hours per day, on an
emergency call-out, for each hour or part thereof over eight hours.
   (D)   Notwithstanding the provisions of division (B) above, no overtime
computation shall be made for a paid holiday, if the holiday falls on a
Saturday or Sunday; provided however, that in such cases a compensatory day off
shall be given the following work weeks (village safety forces excepted).
   (E)   Notwithstanding the provisions of divisions (B) and (D) above,
employees of the Street Department shall be paid at their ordinary hourly rate,
should such employee be granted sick leave, with sick pay on a Saturday, but
only for a maximum of four hours.
(Ord. 4-1979, passed 2-20-79; Am. Ord. 23-1979, passed 9-18-79; Am. Ord. 27-
1979, passed 12-4-79; Am. Ord. 21-1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 27-1981,
passed 12-15-81; Am. Ord. 20-1982, passed 12-18-82; Am. Ord. 5-1984, passed 4-
17-84; Am. Ord. 12-1987, passed 7-21-87; Am. Ord. 15-1988, passed 7-5-88; Am.
Ord. 10-1989, passed 6-20-89; Am. Ord. 5- 1990, passed 6-29-90; Am. Ord. 15-
1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 6- 1992, passed 5-19-92; Am. Ord. 7-1992, passed
5-19-1992)
§ 39.21 EXCEPTION FOR CERTAIN HOLIDAYS.
   Notwithstanding the provisions of §
39.20(B), no overtime computation shall be made for a paid holiday, if the
holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday. However, in such a case a compensatory
day off shall be given the following work week, safety forces excepted.
(Ord. 23-1979, passed 9-18-79; Am. Ord. 27-1979, passed 12-4-79; Am. Ord. 21-
1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 3-981, passed 2-3-81; Am. Ord. 27-1981, passed
12-15-81; Am. Ord. 20-1982, passed 12-18-82; Am. Ord. 5-1984, passed 4-17-84;
Am. Ord. 12-1987, passed 7-21-87; Am. Ord. 15- 1988, passed 7-5-88; Am. Ord.
10-1989, passed 6-20-89; Am. Ord. 5-1990, passed 6-29-90; Am. Ord. 15-1991,
passed 6-18-91)
§ 39.22 EXCEPTION FOR STREET DEPARTMENT EMPLOYEES.
   Notwithstanding the provisions of §§
39.20(B) and
39.21, employees of the village street department shall be paid at their
ordinary hourly rate, should such employee be granted sick leave with sick pay
on Saturday, but only for a maximum of four hours.
(Ord. 23-1979, passed 9-18-79; Am. Ord. 27-1979, passed 12-4-79; Am. Ord. 21-
1980, passed 12-16-80; Am. Ord. 27-1981, passed 12-15-81; Am. Ord. 20-1982,
passed 12-18-82; Am. Ord. 5-1984, passed 4-17-84; Am. Ord. 12-1987, passed 7-

Ord. 5-1990, passed 6-29-90; Am. Ord. 15- 1991, passed 6-18-91)
§ 39.30 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   All newly hired employees are subject to a 6-month probationary period.
(Ord. 4-1988, passed 1-8-88; Am. Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 6-1992,
passed 5-19-92)
§ 39.31 EMPLOYEES SUBJECT TO CALL.
   All employees provided for herein are subject to call in the event of an
emergency.
(Ord. 4-1988, passed 1-8-88; Am. Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 6-1992,
passed 5-19-92)
§ 39.32 HOLIDAYS FOR EMPLOYEES UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE VILLAGE
ADMINISTRATOR.
   (A)   Holidays, with pay, for all full-time employees shall be as follows:
New Year's Day, Presidents' Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day,
Veterans' Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas, the employee's birthday, and one
personal day (to be granted with at least one week's notice to the appropriate
superior employee or other village officer who shall, in his discretion, grant
or deny a particular request).
   (B)   Any employee who is scheduled or is called to work on a holiday
specified in division (A) above shall be paid for that holiday and, in
addition, shall be paid his hourly-based salary for each hour worked.
(Ord. 4-1988, passed 1-8-88; Am. Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 19-
1997, passed 1-12-98)
§ 39.33 OVERTIME COMPENSATION.
   (A)   For the purpose of computing the first 40 hours per week for any
overtime payment calculation requirements, the following shall be considered in
making this computation:
      (1)   Actual hours worked;
      (2)   Sick leave, which has been granted with sick pay, on a day-to-day
basis; and
      (3)   Paid holidays, as specified in § 38.32.
   (B)   Time-and-one-half of the hourly based salary shall be paid to any
full-time village employee for working over eight hours per day, on an
emergency call-out, for each hour or part thereof over eight hours.
(Ord. 4-1988, passed 1-8-88; Am. Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91)
§ 39.34 TUITION AND REGISTRATION FEE PAYMENT.
   The Village Administrator will pay tuition, registration fees and related
expenses for those persons attending classes directly relating to the obtaining
of licenses for water and/or wastewater treatment/operation. However, any
employee who leaves the employment of the village within five years after such
payment is made, shall fully reimburse the Board for all such payments and
expenses.
(Ord. 4-1988, passed 1-8-88; Am. Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91; Am. Ord. 6-1992,
passed 5-19-92; Am. Ord. 19-1997, passed 1-12-98)
§ 39.35 VACATIONS.
   Vacation time, with pay, for all full-time village employees shall be as
follows:
   (A)   One year of service; one week.
   (B)   From two years of service up to and including seven years of service;
two weeks. From eight years of service up to and including 14 years of service;
three weeks. For at least 15 years of service; four weeks.
   (C)   Vacation time cannot be accumulated from year to year and vacation
time must be arranged, in advance, with the appropriate superior employee or
officer. In the event of an emergency, and an employee is called to work during
his or her vacation period, he/she shall be paid for his/her vacation and, in
addition, shall be paid time-and-one-half for each hour worked.
(Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91)
§ 39.36 BEREAVEMENT PAY.
   In the event that a member of an employee's immediate family dies (mother,
father, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-law, child, spouse,
grandparent), the employee shall be granted up to three days off or until the
day of the funeral, whichever first occurs, with pay.
(Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91)
§ 39.37 JURY DUTY.
   In the event that an employee is called to jury duty, he or she shall be
paid the difference between his or her pay for jury service and his or her
regular salary or wage (computed on a per diem basis), upon presentation of
written evidence of the jury service.
(Ord. 16-1991, passed 6-18-91)
§ 39.38 PART-TIME HELPER.
   (A)   There is hereby created the position of part-time helper, as an
employee to work under the jurisdiction of the Village Administrator.
   (B)   This position is specifically designated as a part-time position, and
the person or persons employed hereunder shall not work in excess of 24 hours
per week.
   (C)   As a part-time position, any person or persons employed hereunder
shall not be provided any of the supplemental benefits or entitlements provided
to full time employees.
(Ord. 17-1991, passed 7-16-91; Am. Ord. 19-1997, passed 1-12-98; Am. Ord. 6-
2022, passed 2-28-22; Am. Ord. 6A-2022, passed 3-21-22)

WATER
   
51.01   Extension of service
   
51.02   Sprinkling ban
   
51.10   Authority of mayor to declare
   
51.11   Restrictions on water use

51.99   Penalty
§ 51.01 EXTENSION OF SERVICE.
   No further extension of water service shall be made outside the village
limits without the consent of council obtained at a regular meeting of council.
(Ord. 14-1972, passed 5-16-72)
§ 51.02 SPRINKLING BAN.
   No sprinkling of water shall be permitted when the mayor notifies the
residents of the village that the village water tank is undergoing repairs.
(Ord. 28-1971, passed 5-4-71)
§ 51.10 AUTHORITY OF MAYOR TO DECLARE.
   The mayor is hereby granted the authority to declare a "water emergency"
when conditions exist that threaten to create a shortage of water in the
village water supply or water supply system.
(Ord. 18-1988, passed 9-6-88)
§ 51.11 RESTRICTIONS ON WATER USE.
   When a "water emergency" is declared all outdoor water use, including but
not limited to watering and sprinkling lawns and flowers, washing of vehicles
and houses, and filling of swimming pools, is prohibited, with the exception of
the following: watering of vegetable gardens between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and
8:00 p.m.; irrigation for the production of food; maintenance of pets and
livestock; watering by commercial nurseries at a minimum level to maintain
stock (but only to the extent that other water sources are not available or
feasible); fire hydrants for firefighting; health protection purposes (if
specifically approved by the Village Administrator); and make-up water for air
conditioning, cooling towers or refilling after draining for health protection
or repair purposes (if specifically approved by the Village Administrator).
(Ord. 18-1988, passed 9-6-88; Am. Ord. 19-1997, passed 1-12-98) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.12 ENFORCEMENT: WARNING PERIOD.
   (A)   The police department is hereby directed to enforce the provisions of
this subchapter, and may do so upon either witnessing a violation occurring in
the presence of the officer, or by obtaining a written, sworn statement from an
individual, in the same manner as private complaints are filed.
   (B)   No person may be charged with a violation of this subchapter until 48
hours after the declaration of a "water emergency" by the mayor in order to
allow notice of said declaration to be given to users of the water system;
provided, however, that the police department may issue warnings during this
48-hour period.
(Ord. 18-1988, passed 9-6-88) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.13 USE OF STREETS, ALLEYS AND OTHER VILLAGE PROPERTY.
   The village water department, and its contractors, shall have a right of use
of all streets, alleys, and other village owned property for travel to and
from, deliveries, placement of water and other utility lines, and other similar
uses, necessary for construction, improvement, maintenance, and operation of
all water department facilities, including the water treatment plant, well
fields, water lines, elevated water storage tank, and accesses to said
facilities. Nothing in this regulation shall be construed to absolve any party
from responsibility for repair of damages caused to village streets, alleys,
and property, or from responsibility to comply with all other applicable
municipal regulations and sections of the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 14-2016, passed 10-3-16)
§ 51.14 ADOPTION OF RATES FOR WATER SERVICE.
   The schedule of rates for water service to the village's water service
customers, both within and outside of the village shall be set and revised,
from time to time, by Village Council, pursuant to resolutions, which
resolutions shall refer to this §
51.14, and shall set forth fully the various rates to be charged. The current
schedule of such rates shall be incorporated by reference into the Village's
Code of Ordinances and Municipal Regulations, and copies shall be maintained
and prominently posted at Village Hall, at the Village Water Department office,
and on the village website. The initial schedule of such rates, effective with
the effective date of this §
51.14, is attached to Ord. 4-2018 as Exhibit "A," and is incorporated herein by
reference.
(Ord. 4-2018, passed 4-2-18)
§ 51.15 COLLECTION OF WATER AND SANITARY SEWER CHANGES.
   (A)   When any water or sanitary sewer service charge to any village
customer, whether said service is provided within or outside of the village,
remains unpaid for more than 60 days after the bill or invoice for same is
mailed, the village shall serve a written demand for payment to the property
owner, specifying the amount due and giving 15 days from the date of the
written demand in which to make full payment of the unpaid balance and all
unpaid current amounts.
   (B)   When any charge for trash and recyclable refuse service that is paid
for and billed by the village to residential customers remains unpaid for more
than 60 days after the bill or invoice is mailed, the village shall serve a
written demand for payment to the property owner, specifying the amount due and
giving 15 days from the date of the, written demand in which to make full
payment of the unpaid balance and all unpaid current amounts.
   (C)   Service of the written demand under either of the above subsections
shall be by certified mail addressed to the owner at the owner's residence or
at the tax mailing address listed on the Stark County Auditor's website. If the
village receives notice from the Post Office that certified mail service has
not been claimed, service of the written demand may be made to the same address
(es) by ordinary mail, with a new 15 day due date specified herein.
   (D)   Where the unpaid balance, including unpaid current balances, is not
paid within the time specified in the latest written demand, the Clerk-
Treasurer shall certify said failure to Village Council and shall further
certify the amount then due, together with the costs of service of the written
demands, and a 10% penalty, to the Stark County Auditor for placement on the
tax duplicate to be collected as other taxes for return to the village.
   (E)   Alternatively, the village may bring a civil action to collect all
sums due, the village's costs of collection, a 10% penalty, and court costs, in
a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 8-2018, passed 5-7-18)
§ 51.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than $100. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.
('75 Code, § 1044.99) (Ord. 18-1988, passed 9-6-88)
GAS
   
52.01   Customer charges
   
52.02   Terms and conditions of service
   
52.03   Adjustment of rates
§ 52.01 CUSTOMER CHARGES.
   (A) For the period from and after the effective date of this section, and
until May 17, 1986, the maximum price which Columbia Gas of Ohio, Inc., its
successors or assigns, shall be permitted to charge for and the minimum price
at which it or they shall be required to furnish gas to the village and to its
inhabitants, shall be and the same is hereby fixed for each individual consumer
as follows.
      (1)   A customer charge of $5.10, per meter per month, regardless of gas
consumed; and $.10705 per 100 cubic feet, per meter per month, for all gas
consumed.
      (2)   A customer charge for each customer each month of $5.10 shall be
made. If service under this rate schedule is discontinued at the request of the
customer, the company shall not be under any obligation to resume service to
the same customer on the same premises until the customer has made payment of
an amount equal to the customer charge for each month of the intervening
period, but not to exceed 12 months.
   (B)   From and after bills rendered May 17, 1986 and until May 17, 1987, as
follows.
      (1)   A customer charge of $5.10, per meter per month, regardless of gas
consumed; and $.12800 per 100 cubic feet, per meter per month, for all gas
consumed.
      (2)   A customer charge for each customer each month of $5.10 shall be
made. If service under this rate schedule is discontinued at the request of the
customer, the company shall not be under any obligation to resume service to
the same customer on the same premises until the customer has made payment of
an amount equal to the customer charge for each month of the intervening
period, but not to exceed 12 months.
   (C)   From and after bills rendered May 17, 1987 and until May 17, 1988, as
follows.
      (1)   A customer charge of $5.10, per meter per month, regardless of gas
consumed, and $.14900 per 100 cubic feet, per meter per month, for all gas
consumed.
      (2)   A customer charge for each customer each month of $5.10 shall be
made. If service under this rate schedule is discontinued at the request of the
customer, the company shall not be under any obligation to resume service to
the same customer on the same premises until the customer has made payment of
an amount equal to the customer charge for each month of the intervening
period, but not to exceed 12 months.
   (D)   From and after bills rendered May 17, 1988 and until May 17, 1989, as
follows.
      (1)   A customer charge of $5.10, per meter per month, regardless of gas
consumed, and $.17000 per 100 cubic feet, per meter per month, for all gas
consumed.
      (2)   A customer charge for each customer each month of $5.10 shall be
made. If service under this rate schedule is discontinued at the request of the
customer, the company shall not be under any obligation to resume service to
the same customer on the same premises until the customer has made payment of
an amount equal to the customer charge for each month of the intervening
period, but not to exceed 12 months.
   (E)   From and after bills rendered May 17, 1989 and until February 17,
1990, as follows.
      (1)   A customer charge of $5.10, per meter per month, regardless of gas
consumed, and $.19100 per 100 cubic feet, per meter per month, for all gas
consumed.
      (2)   A customer charge for each customer each month of $5.10 shall be
made. If service under this rate schedule is discontinued at the request of the
customer, the company shall not be under any obligation to resume service to
the same customer on the same premises until the customer has made payment of
an amount equal to the customer charge for each month of the intervening
period, but not to exceed 12 months.
   (F)   The above rates exclude gas costs and the state gross receipts tax.
All bills rendered pursuant to this section shall be adjusted to reflect the
effect of the state gross receipts tax and are subject to decrease or increase
in accordance with the gas cost recovery provisions of the company's rules and
regulations, on file with the state public utilities commission.
(Ord. 4-1984, passed 4-17-84; Am. Ord. 13-1984, passed 9-18-84)
§ 52.02 TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF SERVICE.
   (A)   It is expressly conditioned that the service to be rendered by the gas
company, its successors or assigns, pursuant to this chanter shall be primarily
for domestic and commercial purposes, and that service shall not be extended to
other consumers of different classes until after all reasonable requirements
for domestic and commercial purposes are fully met, and this provision shall be
binding upon the company, its successors or assigns, during each month of each
year; but during any month or year, subject to the foregoing limitations and
after compliance with the foregoing provisions, gas may be delivered to any
other consumer and additional classes of consumers at such times and under such
conditions and for such rates as may be agreed upon between the company and
such consumer or consumers.
   (B)   The terms and conditions of the service to be rendered shall conform
with and be subject to the rules and regulations for furnishing gas service of
the company on file with and approved by the state public utilities commission.
   (C)   The gas furnished or delivered pursuant to the terms of this chapter
by the company shall have an average heating value of 1,000 British thermal
units per cubic foot for any consecutive 12-month period, subject to a variance
of not more than 5% upward or downward.
(Ord. 4-1984, passed 4-17-84; Am. Ord. 13-1984, passed 9-18-84)
§ 52.03 ADJUSTMENT OF RATES.
   (A)   In the event the state or the municipality should hereafter impose a
tax upon the company that is not now imposed, or should hereafter increase the
rate of any tax now imposed upon the company above the tax rate now existing,
other than the rate on property listed in the real estate tax list and
duplicate, then the rates prescribed in §
52.01 shall be increased to the extent necessary to compensate the company for
the increase in cost due to such new tax or higher tax rate. This shall be done
in the following manner:
      (1)   If the new tax or higher tax rate is computed in direct relation to
gas sold or revenues received for the sale of gas, the rates set forth herein
shall be adjusted to the extent necessary to recompense the company for the
amount thereof.
      (2)   If the new tax or higher tax rate is not related directly to gas
sold or to revenues received for the sale of gas, then the total dollar effect
thereof upon the cost of serving gas by the company in the municipality shall
be determined, based upon operations of the company in the municipality during
the most recently available 12-month period ending on the last day of the
December preceding the effective date of the new tax or higher tax rate; the
total dollars so computed shall then be divided by the total sales made to the
types of customers covered by this chapter during the same 12-month period and
the rates prescribed herein shall be correspondingly adjusted.
   (B)   The adjustment of the rates prescribed in this section, as provided in
divisions (A)(1) and (A)(2) above, shall be made by rounding the mathematical
result of the computations so prescribed to the nearest $.0025 per 1,000 cubic
feet.
   (C)   The adjusted rate shall be placed in effect and shall apply to all
meter readings occurring on and after the effective date of the statute,
ordinance, or resolution pursuant to which the new tax or increased tax rate is
imposed.
   (D)   Written notification of the adjustment shall be sent to the clerk of
council of the municipality as quickly as possible after the effect of the new
tax or higher tax rate can be determined.
(Ord. 4-1984, passed 4-17-84; Am. Ord. 13-1984, passed 9-18-84)

STORM WATER QUALITY REGULATIONS
   
54.01   Adoption of regulations
§ 54.01 ADOPTION OF REGULATIONS.
   (A)   General: The Stark County Storm Water Quality Regulations as they are
currently effective, and as amended by the Stark County Soil and Water
Conservation District (SWCD) in the future, are adopted by reference and made a
part of these municipal regulations, the same as if set forth in full herein.
The regulations are available on the SWCD website at www.starkswcd.org, set the
standards for erosion and sediment control and post construction water quality
design in the Village of Navarre, and apply to all developments that are
covered by the regulations as specified therein.
   (B)   Monitoring for Compliance.
      (1)   Sites are immediately considered non-compliant for the following
reasons:
         (a)   Soil disturbing activities without an earth disturbance permit.
         (b)   Soil disturbing activities without an approval storm water
pollution prevention plan.
         (c)   Soil disturbing activities without an Ohio EPA NPDES permit.
         (d)   Soil disturbing activities without a pre- construction meeting.
      (2)   Following the initial inspection of erosion and sediment control
devices by the developer’s delegated representative, regular inspections
(bimonthly) will be performed by the Stark County SWCD for compliance with
storm water quality regulations. If it appears that a violation of any of the
regulations has occurred, the owner and developer will be notified of
deficiencies or non-compliance in writing by certified mail, return receipt
requested, if within 30 days after receipt of the letter, the owner or
developer has not rectified the deficiency or received approval of plans for
its correction, a second notice of violation will be issued. The owner or
developer has another 15 days to rectify the violation. If the violation is not
rectified, the violation shall be reported to the village engineer for
consideration of referral to the village solicitor for immediate enforcement of
these regulations.
      (3)   A final inspection will be made to determine if the criteria of the
storm water quality Regulations have been satisfied and a report sent to the
village.
   (C)   Enforcement.
      (1)   If the village engineer determines that a violation exists and
requests the village solicitor in writing, the solicitor shall seek an
injunction to cease work immediately until compliance with these rules. A court
may also order the construction of sediment control improvements for
implementation or other control measures.
      (2)   Nothing in this section and no action taken thereunder shall be
held to exclude such criminal proceedings as may be authorized under the Ohio
Revised Code.
   (D)   Remedies not exclusive. The remedies listed in this regulation are not
exclusive of any other remedies available under any applicable federal, state
or local law and it is in the discretion of the village to seek cumulative
remedies.
   (E)   Penalty. Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Ord. 6-2008, passed 4-7-08; Am. Ord. 6-2015, passed 3-2-15)
TRAFFIC CODE
GENERAL PROVISIONS
   
70.17   Authority and consideration for placement of devices
   
70.18   Conformity with state manual
   
70.19   Powers, records of chief of police
   
70.20   Reservation of power to council
   
70.21   Through truck traffic limited on Market, Wooster and Park Streets
   
70.22   Truck routes and through truck routes in the Village of Navarre
GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 70.17 AUTHORITY AND CONSIDERATION FOR PLACEMENT OF DEVICES.
   The chief of police is hereby authorized to place and maintain traffic
control devices upon any street or highway under his jurisdiction as are
necessary to effectuate the provisions of this traffic code, or to regulate,
warn, or guide traffic, and such other traffic control devices as he shall deem
necessary for the proper control of traffic. The chief shall determine the
location, timing and coordination of traffic control devices upon the basis of
an applicable engineering or traffic investigation and shall consider the
following:
   (A)   The maximum safety and protection of vehicular and pedestrian traffic
from physical injury or property damage.
   (B)   The existing and potential traffic movement, volume, and conditions.
   (C)   The location and frequency of accidents, including studies of remedial
measures.
   (D)   The recommendations of the fire chief.
   (E)   The acceleration of transportation of persons and property by vehicles
so as to expedite travel and promote public safety.
   (F)   The convenience and welfare of the general public in parking,
standing, loading, and unloading; and the use of the streets as affecting
business concerns and places of assembly.
   (G)   Economy in the expenditure of money.
('75 Code, § 406.01)
§ 70.18 CONFORMITY WITH STATE MANUAL.
   All traffic control devices placed pursuant to the provisions of this
Traffic Code shall conform to the state "Manual of Uniform Traffic Control
Devices for Streets and Highways," as set forth in R.C. § 4511.09.
('75 Code, § 406.02)
§ 70.19 POWERS, RECORDS OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (A)   The chief of police is hereby empowered to:
      (1)   Designate any street or highway as a through street or highway and
require that all vehicles stop or yield the right-of-way as may be required
before entering it.
      (2)   Designate any intersection as a stop intersection and require all
vehicles to stop at one or more entrances to that intersection.
      (3)   Designate any intersection as a yield intersection and require all
vehicles to yield the right-of-way as required.
      (4)   Designate any street as a one-way street and require that all
vehicles thereon be moved in one specific direction.
      (5)   Designate and mark lanes to be used by traffic moving in a
particular direction regardless of the centerline of the roadway.
      (6)   Erect signs directing slow-moving traffic to use a designated lane
or allocating specified lanes to traffic moving in the same direction.
      (7)   Designate those portions of any street, where overtaking and
passing other traffic or driving to the left of the center or centerline of the
roadway would be especially hazardous, by appropriate signs or markings on the
street to indicate the beginning and end of such zones. Such zones may be
marked by an auxiliary yellow line placed parallel and to the right of the
normal centerline or offset marked lane line.
      (8)   Place markers, buttons, or signs within or adjacent to
intersections and require that a specific course of direction be traveled by
vehicles proceeding in lanes by either permitting, prohibiting, or requiring
turns at those intersections.
      (9)   Install traffic control devices, signals, and signs at any location
to regulate traffic.
      (10)   Establish safety zones, crosswalks, zones of quiet, and play
streets.
      (11)   Close any street or portion thereof to vehicular traffic which is
in the process of construction, reconstruction, or repair.
      (12)   Determine the location of any necessary bus stops and taxicab
stands.
      (13)   Determine the location and limit hours of truck loading zones.
      (14)   Designate dangerous railroad crossings and erect stop signs
thereat.
      (15)   Erect "No U-Turn" signs at any location to prohibit a vehicle from
being turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction.
      (16)   Regulate or prohibit the stopping, standing, and parking of
vehicles on streets, alleys, or public property by erecting signs plainly
indicating the prohibitions, restrictions, or limitations.
      (17)   Designate individual parking spaces by markings, which
may either be parallel or at a prescribed angle to the curb or edge of the
roadway. ('75 Code, § 406.03)
   (B)   The powers of the chief of police shall not be limited by the specific
enumeration of subjects contained in this subchapter. ('75 Code, § 406.05)
   (C)   The chief of police shall keep a record of all rules, regulations and
proceedings promulgated in connection with this subchapter. ('75 Code, §
406.06)
§ 70.20 RESERVATION OF POWER TO COUNCIL.
   Notwithstanding the provisions of this subchapter, council may override any
decision of the chief of police and may assume any of the powers delegated to
the chief, by a resolution adopted by a vote of a majority of the members duly
elected thereto. Upon the adoption of any such resolution, the same may be
changed only by an amending or repealing resolution adopted by council.
('75 Code, § 406.07)
§ 70.21 THROUGH TRUCK TRAFFIC LIMITED ON MARKET, WOOSTER, AND PARK STREETS.
   (A)   Offense. Through truck traffic shall not be permitted on Market
Street, Wooster Street, or Park Street, within the Village of Navarre. Trucks
are defined to include both semi-tractor trailers (53-foot trailers) and roll-
off trucks, such as the type used to haul garbage to landfills or regulated by
§ 74.44 of these Municipal Regulations. "Through traffic" is define as
traveling from outside the village to outside the village, without stopping for
any legitimate business purpose within the village. Violation of this section
is a minor misdemeanor, and subsequent offenses within one year of a prior
violation of this section is a fourth degree misdemeanor.
   (B)   Violation by an organization. No organization, as defined in R.C. §
2901.2(D), shall permit a truck or roll-off truck owned, leased, or operated by
such organization, to violate division (A) above. Use of a truck or roll-off
truck in violation of this division will constitute prima-facie evidence that
the organization permitted the violation. A violation of this division is a
minor misdemeanor, and subsequent offenses within one year of a prior violation
is a fourth degree misdemeanor, with the maximum fine for each being $1,000 for
a minor misdemeanor and $2,000 for a fourth degree misdemeanor, or such higher
maximums as permitted by he then current version of R.C. § 2929.31.
(Ord. 16-2022, passed 7-18-22; Am. Ord. 14-2023, passed 10-2-23)
§ 70.22 TRUCK ROUTES AND THROUGH TRUCK ROUTES IN THE VILLAGE OF NAVARRE.
   (A)   Through truck traffic shall not be permitted on residential streets
within the Village of Navarre unless otherwise permitted in the village
codified Municipal Regulations. Trucks are defined to include both semi-tractor
trailers (53-foot trailers) and roll-off trucks, such as the type used to haul
garbage to landfills. "Through traffic" is defined as traveling from outside
the village to outside the village without stopping for any legitimate business
purpose within the village.
   (B)   State Route 21 (SR21), United States Route 62 (SR62), Sterilite Street
NE and Canal Street East are designated as "truck routes."
   (C)   Through truck traffic is permitted only on village designated truck
routes.
   (D)   Through truck traffic is not permitted on Wooster Street or other
village residential streets.
   (E)   Through truck traffic approaching the Village of Navarre from the east
on Fohl Street SW shall use Sterilite Street NE to Navarre Road SW as a way
around the residential portion of the village.
   (F)   Through truck traffic approaching the Village of Navarre from the west
on Elton Street SW, shall detour toward SR62 or Warmington Road SW before Elton
Street SW connects with Wooster Street.
   (G)   Wooster Street is not to be used as a "cut-through" for through truck
traffic or truck traffic described in division (H) below.
   (H)   Truck traffic to and from facilities in Prospect Industrial Park along
Sterilite Street NE, that otherwise has no legitimate business purpose for
stopping elsewhere within the village, shall enter and depart Prospect
Industrial Park only from or to Sterilite Street NE-Navarre Road SW or Fohl
Street SW away from the residential portion of the village.
   (I)   Through truck traffic entering the village on a designated truck route
shall pass through the village only on designated truck routes, and shall not
detour onto Wooster Street or other residential streets.
   (J)   Violation of this section is a minor misdemeanor, and a second offense
within one year of a first violation of this section is a fourth degree
misdemeanor.
(Ord. 2-2023, passed 3-20-23)

   This section contains municipal ordinances which supercede the Ohio Basic
Code section of the same number.
§ 72.13 RULES FOR TURNS AT INTERSECTIONS.
   (A)   The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall be
governed by the following rules:
      (1)   Approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close
as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway.
      (2)   At any intersection where traffic is permitted to move in both
directions on each roadway entering the intersection, an approach for a left
turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the
center line thereof and by passing to the right of the center line where it
enters the intersection, and, after entering the intersection, the left turn
shall be made so as to leave the intersection to the right of the center line
of the roadway being entered. Whenever practicable, the left turn shall be made
in that portion of the intersection to the left of the center of the
intersection.
      (3)   At any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on
one or more of the roadways, the driver of a vehicle intending to turn left at
any such intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme left-hand
lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of the
vehicle, and, after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so
as to leave the intersection, as nearly as practicable, in the left hand lane
of the roadway being entered lawfully available to traffic moving in that lane.
   (B)   The department of transportation and local authorities may cause
markers, buttons, or signs to be placed within or adjacent to intersections,
and thereby require and direct that a different course from that specified in
this section be traveled by vehicles turning at an intersection, and when
markers, buttons, or signs are so placed, no operator of a vehicle shall turn
the vehicle at an intersection other than as directed and required by the
markers, buttons, or signs.
(R.C. § 4511.36) Penalty, see §
70.99
   (C)   The driver of a vehicle intending to turn into a private road or
driveway, alley, or building from a public street or highway shall be governed
by the following rules:
      (l)   Approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close
as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway.
      (2)   Upon a roadway where traffic is proceeding in opposite directions,
approach for a left turn and a left turn shall be made from that portion of the
right half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof.
      (3)   Upon a roadway where traffic is restricted to one direction,
approach for a left turn and a left turn shall be made as close as practicable
to the left-hand curb or edge of the roadway.
      (4)   It shall be the duty of the driver of any vehicle entering a
private road or driveway, alley, or building to yield the right-of-way to
pedestrians lawfully using the sidewalk or sidewalk area extending across the
private roadway or driveway, alley, or building.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-1-75) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.14 TURNING IN ROADWAY PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction
upon any curve, or upon the approach to or near the crest of a grade, if such
vehicle cannot be seen within 500 feet by the driver of any other vehicle
approaching from either direction.
(R.C. § 4511.37)
   (B)   No vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction
within an intersection; upon any street in a business district; upon a freeway,
expressway, or controlled-access highway: or where authorized signs are erected
to prohibit such movements or at any other location unless such movement can be
made with reasonable safety to other users of the public way and without
interfering with the safe operation of any traffic that may be affected by such
movement. (Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75)
Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.18 ZONES OF QUIET.
   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, no person
operating a vehicle within any such zone shall sound the horn or otter warning
device of that vehicle except in an emergency.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.40 BOARDING OR ALIGHTING FROM VEHICLE.
   No person shall board or alight from any moving vehicle or ride upon any
portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers when the
vehicle is in motion, nor shall any operator knowingly permit the same to be
done. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary
discharge of a duty, or riding within a truck body in space designed for
merchandise.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.41 CLIMBING UPON RAILROAD CARS.
   (A)   No person shall climb, jump, step or stand upon or cling or attach
himself to a locomotive, engine or car upon the track of a railroad, unless in
compliance with law or by permission under the rules and regulations of the
corporation managing such railroad. (R.C. § 4999.02)
   (B)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. (Ord.
3-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.45 LICENSE REQUIREMENT.
   No person or entity shall operate as a collector of solid waste or
recyclables for compensation within the corporate limits of the village without
first obtaining a collection license for such activity. The following persons
or entities are not required to obtain a collection license:
   (A)   A civic, community, benevolent, or charitable nonprofit organization
that collects, transports, and markets recyclable materials solely for the
benefit of raising funds for a charitable, civic, or benevolent activity or
purpose;
   (B)   A person or entity that transports solid waste or recyclable materials
produced by such person or entity;
   (C)   A property owner or agent thereof that transports solid waste or
recyclable materials left by a tenant upon such owner's property, so long as
such property owner does not provide solid waste or recyclables collection
service for compensation for tenants on a regular or continuing basis; and
   (D)   A demolition or construction contractor or landscaper that produces
solid waste in the course of such occupation, where the solid waste is merely
incidental to the particular demolition or construction work being performed by
such person or entity.
(Ord. 28-2018, passed 2-18-19)
§ 72.46 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person or entity desiring to obtain a license to engage in the business
of solid waste or recyclables collection shall make written application to the
Village Clerk-Treasurer on forms provided by the village. The application shall
include, without limitation, the following information:
   (A)   The name, address, phone number, and email of the applicant;
   (B)   The name, address, phone number, and email of the applicant's primary
contact person;
   (C)   A list of vehicles owned and/or operated by the applicant directly in
the collection of solid waste and/or recyclables within the village, including
vehicle make, year, cubic yard capacity, Ohio license plate number, and empty
vehicle weight; and
   (D)   A list of commercial customers for whom the applicant has provided, or
is currently providing solid waste or recyclables collection service.
(Ord. 28-2018, passed 2-18-19)
§ 72.47 LICENSE REQUIREMENT, FEES, AND INSURANCE.
   Upon approval of a license application, but prior to issuance, the collector
shall furnish to the Village Clerk-Treasurer the following:
   (A)   A license fee in the sum of $25 for each vehicle to be used for the
purpose of collection of solid waste and recyclables within the Village,
provided that such a license fee shall not be required for a license procured
for use in the calendar year 2019; and
   (B)   Proof that the collector has obtained a general comprehensive
liability/vehicle insurance policy protecting the collector from all claims for
damage to property or for bodily injury, including death, which may arise from
the operations under or in connection with this license and providing limits of
coverage of not less than $250,000 for bodily injury and property damage per
occurrence and in the aggregate.
(Ord. 28-2018, passed 2-18-19)
§ 72.48 TERM OF LICENSE.
   All licenses issued pursuant to §§
74.45 through
74.47 shall run from the date of the issuance until the thirty-first day of
December of the year in which such license is issued. All licenses shall expire
on December 31 of each year. Licenses are not transferable.
(Ord. 28-2018, passed 2-18-19)
§ 72.49 EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   In addition to all other applicable requirements, each vehicle in the
solid waste or recyclable materials collection business shall bear the name and
phone number of the licensed collector providing such service. All commercial
solid waste containers shall bear the name and phone number of the contracted
collector.
   (B)   The Village Administrator or Village Police Chief shall have the right
to cause or participate in periodic inspection of all licensed collectors'
equipment, including vehicles and refuse containers, utilized within the
village, to insure their safe, sanitary, and aesthetic condition. It shall be
the responsibility of collectors to maintain their equipment in a safe,
sanitary, and slightly condition.
(Ord. 28-2018, passed 2-18-19)
§ 72.58 DRIVING UPON SIDEWALK AREA OR PATHS EXCLUSIVELY FOR BICYCLES; PRIVATE
PROPERTY.
   (A)   No person shall drive any vehicle, other than a bicycle, upon a
sidewalk or sidewalk area, except upon a permanent or duly authorized temporary
driveway.
   (B)   Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting local
authorities from regulating the operation of bicycles.
(R.C. § 4511.711)
   (C)   No person shall operate a motor vehicle, snowmobile, or all- purpose
vehicle upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, when an
appropriate sign giving notice of such use is posted on the path.
   (D)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect any rule of the
director of natural resources governing the operation of motor vehicles,
snowmobiles, all-purpose vehicles, and bicycles on lands under his
jurisdiction.
(R.C. § 4511.713)
   (E)   No operator of a motor vehicle shall enter upon private property for
the sole purpose of driving across that property, between abutting streets or
other public ways thereof. The failure to stop on the property in connection
with or in furtherance of the objects of enterprise or activities being
conducted on the property shall constitute prima-facie evidence of the
violation. (Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75)
§ 72.643 "PEELING"; CRACKING EXHAUST NOISES.
   No person shall operate any motor vehicle, except when necessary for safe
operation, or in compliance with law, in such a manner that the vehicle is so
rapidly accelerated or started from a stopped position, or in the shifting of
gears while in motion, that the exhaust system emits a loud, cracking, or
chattering noise unusual to its normal operation, or that the rubber tires of
the vehicle squeal or leave tire marks on the roadway, commonly known as
"peeling."
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.80 PLAY STREETS.
   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that any street or part
thereof is a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street
or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose
residences are within the closed area, and then those drivers shall exercise
the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.81 TOY VEHICLES ON ROADWAY.
   No person riding upon any coaster, roller skates, sled, toy vehicle, or
other similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street
on a crosswalk, and when so crossing such person shall be granted all of the
rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians.
This section shall not apply to any street set aside as a play street.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of
Chapter 72 of the village's municipal regulations is guilty of and may be
charged with a minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 18-2021, passed 12-20-21)

§ 73.08 WEAVING.
   No person shall drive a vehicle upon any street in a weaving or zigzag
course, unless the irregular course is made necessary by traffic exigencies.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.14 SPEED LIMITATIONS ON BRIDGES.
   (A)   No person shall operate a vehicle over any bridge or other elevated
structure constituting a part of a street at a speed which is greater than the
maximum speed that can be maintained with safety to such bridge or structure,
when such structure is posted with authorized signs stating such maximum speed.
Such signs shall be erected and maintained at a distance of at least 100 feet
before each end of such structure.
   (B)   Upon the trial of any person charged with a violation of this section,
proof of the determination of the maximum speed and the existence of such signs
shall constitute prima-facie evidence of the maximum speed which can be
maintained with safety to such bridges or structure.
(R.C. § 4511.23) (Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.17 USE OF FICTITIOUS NAME AFTER CITATION.
   No person charged with violating any of the provisions of this traffic code
shall present a citation tag or file a written plea of guilty with the clerk of
the mayor's court or the mayor or with any other court under a name other than
his correct and true name.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.31 OPERATING WITH EXPIRED PLATES.
   No person shall operate any vehicle upon which are displayed any license
number for any period of time which has expired or any license plates issued in
another state for which the period of reciprocal agreement with the state of
issued has expired.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.32 OPERATING WITH LICENSE NUMBERS NOT LEGALLY REGISTERED.
   No person shall operate any vehicle upon which are displayed any license
numbers not legally registered and issued for that vehicle or upon which are
displayed any license numbers that were issued on an application for
registration that contained any false statements by the applicant.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
73.99

   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of
Chapter 73 of the village's municipal regulations is guilty of and may be
charged with a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 18-2021, passed 12-20-21)

§ 74.26 HORNS, SIRENS, AND WARNING DEVICES.
   (A)   Every motor vehicle when operated upon a highway shall be equipped
with a horn which is in good working order and capable of emitting sound
audible, under normal conditions, from a distance of not less than 200 feet.
   (B)   No motor vehicle shall be equipped with, nor shall any person use upon
a vehicle, any siren, whistle, or bell. Any vehicle may be equipped with a
theft alarm signal device which shall be so arranged that it cannot be used as
an ordinary warning signal. Every emergency vehicle shall be equipped with a
siren, whistle, or bell, capable of emitting sound audible under normal
conditions from a distance of not less than 500 feet and of a type approved by
the director of highway safety, Such equipment shall not be used except when
such vehicle is operated in response to an emergency call or is in the
immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, in which case
the driver of the emergency vehicle shall sound such equipment when it is
necessary to warn pedestrians and other drivers of the approach thereof. (R.C.
§ 4513.21)
   (C)   No person shall sound any signaling device except when reasonably
necessary for the prevention of an accident. (Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 74.29 WINDSHIELDS AND WIPERS.
   (A)   No person shall drive any motor vehicle, other than a bus, with any
sign, poster, or other nontransparent material upon the front windshield,
sidewings, side, or rear windows of such vehicle other than a certificate or
other paper required to be displayed by law, except that there may be in the
lower right-hand corner of the windshield a sign or poster not to exceed 4
inches in height by 6 inches in width.
   (B)   The windshield on every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a device
for cleaning rain, snow, or other moisture from the windshield, which device
shall be maintained in good working order and so constructed as to be
controlled or operated by the operator of the vehicle. (R.C. § 4513.24)
Penalty, see §
70.99
   (C)   No person shall operate or have upon any street any vehicle in which
the operator's view through the windshield of any window is obstructed, due to
the glass being dirty, cracked, blurred, or otherwise nontransparent. (Ord.
874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 74.39 SPIKES, LUGS, AND CHAINS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "STUDDED TIRE." Any tire designed for use on a vehicle, and equipped with
metal studs or studs of wear-resisting material that project beyond the tread
of the traction surface of the tire. (R.C. § 5589.081)
   "TRACTION ENGINE" or "TRACTOR." All self-propelling engines equipped with
metal-tired wheels operated or propelled by any form of engine, motor, or
mechanical power.
   (B)   No person shall drive over the improved streets of this municipality a
traction engine or tractor with tires or wheels equipped with ice picks, spuds,
spikes, chains, or other projections of any kind extending beyond the cleats,
or no person shall tow or in any way pull another vehicle over the improved
streets of this municipality, which towed or pulled vehicle has tires or wheels
equipped with ice picks, spuds, spikes, chains, or other projections of any
kind.
(R.C. § 5589.08)
§ 74.40 LOAD LIMITS; SPECIAL PERMITS.
   (A)   State routes.
      (l)   No person shall operate or move a vehicle or combination of
vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the maximum specified
in R.C. §§ 5577.01 through 5577.09, or otherwise not in conformity with R.C. §§
4513.01 through 4513.37, upon any state route within the municipality, except
pursuant to special written permit issued by the state director of
transportation. Every such permit shall be carried in the vehicle or
combination of vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by
any police officer.
      (2)   No holder of a permit issued by the state director of
transportation shall be required to obtain any local permit or license or pay
any local fee or charge for movement on any state route within the
municipality. However, no person shall operate any such vehicle or combination
of vehicles upon any roadway within the municipality which is not a state
route, except as may be otherwise provided in any local ordinance or regulation
or elsewhere in this traffic code.
   (B)   Local streets.
      (l)   No person shall operate a vehicle exceeding a size as specified in
§ 74.38 or exceeding a gross weight of five tons, upon any street in the
municipality other than state routes and county roads, except those local
streets designated as a truck route and marked as such by appropriate traffic
signs, and except when such operation is necessary to load or unload property,
to go to or from the usual place of storage of the vehicle, or to perform any
other legitimate business or act other than passage through the municipality.
Operators of vehicles so deviating from either a state route or a designated
truck route within the municipality shall confine such deviation to that
required in order to accomplish the purpose of the departure.
      (2)   On county roads council or other duly designated local authority
shall establish reasonable weight limits commensurate with the construction and
material specifications for those roads and the load resistance of those roads
as determined by the county engineer. County roads shall be posted with signs
indicating weight limits.
   (C)   Local permit and conditions.
      (l)   Upon application and for good cause, the police chief may issue a
local permit authorizing an applicant to move an oversize or overweight vehicle
or combination of vehicles upon local streets and highways. No permittee shall
be required to obtain a special permit from the state director of
transportation for the movement of the vehicle or combination of vehicles on
streets or highways under local jurisdiction. However, the approval of the
state director of transportation shall be required for movement upon state
routes as provided in R.C. § 4513.34.
      (2)   The police chief may grant a permit for a single or round trip, or
for such period of time, not to exceed one year, as the police chief in his
discretion deems advisable, or for the duration of any construction project.
The police chief may limit or prescribe terms or conditions of operation for
the vehicle or combination of vehicles by designating the route, hours, speed,
or such other restrictions as may be necessary for the preservation of the
public peace, property, health, and safety. The police chief may require the
posting of bond or other security necessary to compensate for any damage to a
roadway or road structure.
      (3)   For each such permit, the police chief shall charge $2, and for
each hour of time or any part thereof spent by the police department in
supervising the movement of the vehicle, the applicant shall pay the sum of $5.
      (4)   Except as provided in division (B) hereof, streets and highways
shall be posted with signs indicating "no through trucks - gross weight 5 tons"
or words of similar import to apprise drivers of the limitations imposed by
this section. No driver shall disobey the instructions indicated on any such
sign.
      (5)   Violation of any of the limitations, terms, or conditions of the
permit granted by the police chief shall be cause for immediate revocation or
suspension of that permit and denial of request for any future permit.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 74.42 ALL LOADS SHALL BE PROPERLY SECURED.
   (A)   (l)   No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any highway unless the
vehicle is so constructed, loaded, or covered as to prevent any of its load
from dropping, sifting, leaking, or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that
sand or other substance may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or
water or other substance may be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or
maintaining the roadway.
      (2)   Except for a farm vehicle used to transport agricultural produce or
agricultural production materials or a rubbish vehicle in the process of
acquiring its load, no vehicle loaded with garbage, swill, cans, bottles, waste
paper, ashes, refuse, trash, rubbish, waste, wire, paper, cartons, boxes,
glass, solid waste, or any other material of an unsanitary nature that is
susceptible to blowing or bouncing from a moving vehicle shall be driven or
moved on any highway unless the load is covered with a sufficient cover to
prevent the load or any part of the load, from spilling onto the highway.
(R.C. § 4513.31)
   (B)   No person shall operate any vehicle upon a street unless that vehicle
is so loaded as to prevent its contents from shifting or otherwise unbalancing
the vehicle to such an extent as to interfere with the safe operation thereof.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
   (C)   No person shall operate any vehicle so as to track mud on any public
way or place.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of the driver of a vehicle who unlawfully drops
or deposits mud or permits the load or any portion thereof to be dropped or
deposited upon any public way or place to immediately remove the same or cause
it to be removed.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 74.43 USE OF VILLAGE STREETS AND ALLEYS BY COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL USE.
   (A)   “ALLEY” means a street or highway intended to provide access to the
rear side of lots or buildings within the village, and not intended for the
purpose of through vehicular traffic, and includes any street or highway that
has been declared an “ALLEY” by Village Council or by the Village
Administrator, Police Chief, or Superintendent of Streets.
   (B)   Commercial and industrial users, including without limitation
collectors and haulers of solid waste and recyclables, shall not use village
streets and alleys in such a way as to obstruct free traffic flow through or to
damage them. Such users shall obey all directives from the Village
Administrator, Police Chief, or Superintendent of Streets, in the use or non-
use of any streets and alleys, and a directive from any of the foregoing shall
be final and binding upon such users. Alleys may be used by collector and
haulers of solid waste and recyclables only to access an alley-side collection
point; otherwise such users may not use village alleys. Double axle vehicles,
and single axle vehicles with an empty or dry weight of more than 10,000 pounds
shall not use any portion of village alleys that lie wholly within a
residential zone. Commercial and industrial users shall take care not to
interfere with or damage above-ground utility lines, and are responsible for
damage thereto caused by such users.
(Ord. 24-2018, passed 2-4-19)
§ 74.44 HOURS OF OPERATION WITHIN VILLAGE BY COLLECTORS AND HAULERS OF SOLID
WASTE AND RECYCLABLES.
   No collector or hauler of solid waste or recyclables shall operate any
vehicle for the purpose of collection of solid waste or recyclable materials
within the village between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.
(Ord. 24-2018, passed 2-4-19)
§ 74.99 PENALTIES.
   Whoever violates of fails to comply with any provision of Chapter 74 of the
village's municipal regulations is guilty of and may be charged with a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 24-2018, passed 2-4-19)

§ 75.01 BICYCLES.
   (A)   The provisions of this title which are applicable to bicycles apply
whenever a bicycle is operated upon any highway or upon any path set aside for
the exclusive use of bicycles. (R.C. § 4511.52)
   (B)   Every person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of
official traffic-control devices and signals applicable to vehicles, unless
otherwise directed by a police officer. (Ord. 1-1975, passed 1- 7-75) Penalty,
see §
75.99
§ 75.07 RIDING BICYCLES UPON SIDEWALKS.
   A person operating a bicycle shall ride upon the sidewalk rather than the
roadway when sidewalks are available, except that no person shall ride a
bicycle upon a sidewalk upon or along which signs have been erected by
authority of council or other duly designated local authority prohibiting such
bicycle riding, or within a business district. At no time shall a person under
the age of 11 years operate a bicycle on a street.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75)
