   Street and sidewalk regulations,
Ch. 95
§ 75.08 SAFE RIDING REGULATIONS FOR BICYCLES.
   (A)   Whenever a designated usable path for bicycles has been provided
adjacent to a street, bicycle riders shall use that path and shall not use the
street.
   (B)   Whenever a person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk or street, that
person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible
signal before attempting to overtake and pass a pedestrian or another bicycle.
This audible signal must be given only by bell or other warning device capable
of giving an audible signal and shall be given at such a distance and in such a
manner as not to startle the person being overtaken and passed.
   (C)   No person shall ride a bicycle across or through any intersection
involving a through street. These intersections are to be crossed by walking
the bicycle across or through the intersection.
   (D)   Whenever a person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, the person,
before overtaking and passing a blind person carrying a white or metallic cane,
shall dismount and overtake or pass on foot.
   (E)   When a bicycle is operated on the street, the operator shall give hand
signals before turning, changing lanes, or stopping. These signals shall
conform with § 72.17.
   (F)   Every rider of a bicycle shall exercise due care to-avoid colliding
with any pedestrian or any vehicle upon any roadway, sidewalk, or bicycle path,
or endangering the life, limb or property of any person while in the lawful use
of the streets, sidewalks, or any other private or public property.
   (G)   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is
reasonable and proper under the conditions then existing.
   (H)   The operator of a bicycle emerging from or turning into an alley,
driveway, or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area
extending across any alley, driveway, or building, yield the right-of-way to
all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk area. Upon entering the street, the
operator shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such
street.
   (I)   No person shall engage in trick riding or operate a bicycle without
both hands upon the handle grips except when necessary to give the hand signals
required herein.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.09 PARKING; LOCKS.
   (A)   No person shall park a bicycle upon a sidewalk in such a manner as to
interfere with pede8trian traffic or damage the property of another.
   (B)   No person shall park a bicycle upon a roadway in such a manner as to
interfere with vehicular traffic.
   (C)   No bicycle shall remain unlocked when parked upon any public way or
place.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.10 PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   No parent of any child or guardian of any ward shall authorize or knowingly
permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.11 SUSPENSION OF RIDING PRIVILEGES; IMPOUNDING OF BICYCLES.
   In addition to the penalties provided in §
70.99, a court may prohibit any person who violates or fails to comply with any
of the provisions of this chapter relating to bicycles from riding a bicycle
for a period not to exceed three months. In addition, any person violating or
failing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter relating to
bicycles may be punished by having his bicycle impounded for a period not
exceeding 30 days.
(Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75)
§ 75.12 MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLES RESTRICTED.
   (A)   Motor-driven, two-wheel cycles shall be restricted in use to the
roadways provided for passage within the village parks.
   (B)   No person shall drive or ride a motor-driven two-wheel cycle in
village parks, while upon the roadways passing through such parks, so as to
endanger the life or property of others using such roadways.
   (C)   Notwithstanding the provisions stated in divisions (A) and (B) hereof,
this section Shall not apply to nonmotor-driven two-wheel cycles, nor to two-
wheel cycles whose primary source of power is not motorized.
(Ord. 10-1974, passed 6-4-74) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.20 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "ALL PURPOSE VEHICLE." Any self-propelled vehicle designed primarily for
cross-country travel on land and water, or on more than one type of terrain,
and steered by wheels or caterpillar treads, or any combination thereof,
including vehicles that operate on a cushion of air, vehicles commonly known as
all-terrain vehicles, all season vehicles, mini-bikes, and trail bikes, but
excluding any self-propelled vehicle not principally used for purposes of
personal transportation, any vehicle principally used in playing golf, any
motor vehicle or aircraft required to be registered under R.C. Chapters 4503 or
4561 and any vehicle excepted from definition as a motor vehicle by § 70.01.
   "INTERSTATE HIGHWAY." Any part of the interstate system of highways as
defined in subsection (e), 90 Stat. 431 (1976), 23 U.S.C. 103, and amendments
thereof.
   "LIMITED ACCESS HIGHWAY" or "FREEWAY." Have the same meaning as is given
those terms in R.C. § 5511.02.
   "OPERATOR." Any person who operates or is in actual physical control of a
snowmobile or all purpose vehicle.
   "OWNER." Any person, firm, or corporation, other than a lienholder or
dealer, having title to a snowmobile or all purpose vehicle, or other right to
the possession thereof.
   "SNOWMOBILE." Any self-propelled vehicle designed primarily for use on snow
or ice, and steered by skis, runners or caterpillar treads.
(R.C. § 4519.01)
§ 75.21 EQUIPMENT.
   Equipment of snowmobiles and all purpose vehicles shall include, but not
necessarily be limited to requirements for the following items:
   (A)   At least one headlight having a minimum candlepower of sufficient
intensity to reveal persons and objects at a distance of at least 100 feet
ahead under normal atmospheric conditions during hours of darkness.
   (B)   At least one red tail light having a minimum candlepower of sufficient
intensity to be plainly visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear under
normal atmospheric conditions during hours of darkness.
   (C)   Adequate brakes. Every snowmobile shall, while traveling on packed
snow, be capable of carrying a driver who weighs 175 pounds or more, and, while
carrying such driver, be capable of stopping in not more than 40 feet room in
initial steady speed of 20 miles per hour, or locking its traction belt.
   (D)   A muffler system capable of precluding the emission of excessive smoke
or exhaust fumes, and of limiting the engine noise of vehicles. On snowmobiles
manufactured after January 1, 1973, such requirement shall include sound
dampening equipment such that noise does not exceed 82 decibels on the "A"
scale at 50 feet as measured according to SAE J192 (September 1970).
   (E)   No person shall operate any snowmobile or all purpose vehicle in
violation of this section, except that equipment specified in divisions (A) and
(B) hereof shall not be required on snowmobiles or all purpose vehicles
operated during the daylight hours on state controlled land under the
jurisdiction of the state department of natural resources and that are limited
to off-highway use.
(R.C. § 4519.20) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.22 CODE APPLICATION; PROHIBITED OPERATION.
   (A)   The applicable provisions of this traffic code shall be applied to the
operation of snowmobiles and all purpose vehicles, except that no snowmobile or
all purpose vehicle shall be operated as follows:
      (l)   On any limited access highway, freeway, or the right-of- way
thereof, except for emergency travel only during such time and in such manner
as the state director of highway safety shall designate.
      (2)   On any private property, or in any nursery or planting area,
without the permission of the owner or other person having the right to
possession of the property.
      (3)   On any land or waters controlled by the state, except at those
locations where a sign has been posted permitting such operation.
      (4)   On the tracks or right-of-way of any operating railroad.
      (5)   While transporting any firearm, bow, or other implement for
hunting, that is not unloaded and securely encased.
      (6)   For the purpose of chasing, pursuing, capturing, or killing any
animal or wild fowl.
      (7)   During the time from one-half hour after sunset to one- half hour
before sunrise, unless displaying lighted lights as required by §
75.21.
(R.C. § 4519.40)
   (B)   Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be fined not
less than $50 nor more than $500 or imprisoned not less than three nor more
than 30 days, or both. (R.C. § 4519.99 (D))
§ 75.23 PERMITTED OPERATION.
   Snowmobiles and all purpose vehicles being used for winter travel may be
operated as follows:
   (A)   To make a crossing of a highway, other than a highway as designated in
§
75.22(A)(l), whenever the crossing can be made in safety and will not interfere
with the movement of vehicular traffic approaching from any direction on the
highway, and provided that the operator yields the right-of-way to any
approaching traffic that presents an immediate hazard.
   (B)   On highways in the county or township road systems whenever the local
authority having jurisdiction over such highways so permits.
   (C)   Off and alongside a street or highway for limited distances from the
point of unloading from a conveyance to the point at which the snowmobile or
all purpose vehicle is intended and authorized to be operated.
   (D)   On the berm or shoulder of a highway, other than a highway as
designated in §
75.22(A)(l), when the terrain permits such operation to be undertaken safely
and without the necessity of entering any traffic lane.
(R.C. § 4519.41)
§ 75.24 LICENSING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   No person who does not hold a valid, current motor vehicle operator's
or chauffeur's license, motorcycle operator's endorsement, or probationary
license issued under R.C. Ch. 4507, shall operate a snowmobile or all purpose
vehicle on any street or highway in this municipality, on any portion of the
right-of-way thereof, or on any public land or waters.
   (B)   No person who is less than 16 years of age shall operate a snowmobile
or all purpose vehicle on any land or waters other than private property or
waters owned by or leased to such person's parent or guardian, unless
accompanied by another person who is 18 years of age, or older, and who holds a
license as provided in division (A) hereof, except that the state department of
natural resources may permit such operation on state controlled land under its
jurisdiction
when such person is less than 16 years of age but is 12 years of age or older
and is accompanied by a parent or guardian who is a licensed driver 18 years of
age or older. (R.C. § 4519.44)
   (C)   Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be fined not
less than $50 nor more than S500 or imprisoned not less than three nor more
than 30 days, or both. (R.C. § 4519.99(D))
§ 75.25 ACCIDENT REPORTS.
   (A)   The operator of a snowmobile or all purpose vehicle involved in any
accident resulting in bodily injury to or death of any person or damage to the
property of any person in excess of $100 shall report the accident within 48
hours to the chief of police, and shall within 30 days forward a written report
of the accident to the state registrar of motor vehicles on a form prescribed
by the registrar. If the operator is physically incapable of making the reports
and there is another participant in the accident not so incapacitated, such
participant shall make the reports. In the event that there is no other
participant, and the operator i8 other than the owner, the owner shall, within
the prescribed periods of time, make the reports.
   (B)   Any law enforcement officer or other person authorized by R.C. §§
4519.42 and 4519.43, who investigates or receives information of an accident
involving a snowmobile or all purpose vehicle shall forward to the registrar a
written report of the accident within 48 hours. (R.C. § 4519.46)
   (C)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third
degree. (Ord. 1-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
75.99
§ 75.26 LOCAL CONTROL WITHIN POLICE POWER.
   Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent the municipality from
regulating the operation of snowmobiles and all purpose vehicles on streets and
highways and other public property under municipal jurisdiction, and within the
reasonable exercise of the police power, except that the registration or
licensing of any snowmobile or all purpose vehicle required to be registered
under R.C. Chapter 4519 shall not be required. (R.C. § 4519.48)
§ 75.27 USE OF AND DEFINITION OF UNDER SPEED VEHICLES.
   (A)   Subject to the requirements set forth in §§
75.27 through
75.31 herein, the use of "under speed vehicles" (commonly referred to as "golf
carts" and defined in §
34.22), shall be permitted on village streets where the speed limit is 25 miles
per hour or less, provided further that such use may not occur on streets that
are designated as either a State of Ohio or federal road or highway.
   (B)   Under speed vehicles shall be permitted to cross Ohio or federal roads
or highways at only two locations: across U. S. Route 62 at Sisterhen Court NW;
and across Ohio Route 21/U. S. Route 62 at the lighted intersection with
Wooster Street.
(Ord. 2-2022, passed 2-7-22)
§ 75.28 INSPECTION.
   (A)   Prior to the operation of an under speed vehicle on village streets,
the under speed vehicle must pass an inspection conducted by the Navarre Police
Department, that complies with inspection requirements established by the Ohio
Department of Public Safety (DPS-1373), and possess a valid Village of Navarre
under speed vehicle permit issued by the Navarre Police Department.
   (B)   If an under speed vehicle passes inspection, the owner/operator will
be permitted to operate the under speed vehicle on village streets in
compliance with §
75.27.
   (C)   The Navarre Police Department shall have the right to not issue a
permit to any applicant for any or no reason. Further, the Navarre Police
Department shall have the right to revoke any permit, for any or no reason,
that had been previously issued.
(Ord. 2-2022, passed 2-7-22)
§ 75.29 REGISTRATION.
   Prior to operation of an under speed vehicle on village streets, the vehicle
must be registered in accordance with R.C. Chapter 4503, and be titled in
accordance with R.C. Chapter 4505. Out of state under speed vehicles are not
permitted on village streets.
(Ord. 2-2022, passed 2-7-22)
§ 75.30 OPERATION.
   All under speed vehicles must be operated in accordance with all applicable
federal, state, and local traffic laws. No one shall use any under speed
vehicle on any public sidewalks nor in any public parks. Anyone who operated an
under speed vehicle on village streets must have a valid driver's license. All
child restraints must be used in accordance with all applicable federal, state,
and local traffic laws. All seatbelts are required to be used in accordance
with all applicable federal, state, and local traffic laws as they apply to
automobiles and/or motor vehicles as defined in the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 2-2022, passed 2-7-22)
§ 75.31 REQUIRED EQUIPMENT.
   All under speed vehicles, at a minimum, must have the following properly
functioning equipment:
   (A)   Two brake lights, two head lights, two front and two rear turn
signals, one rear tail light, and a white rear license plate light;
   (B)   A horn;
   (C)   A rearview mirror;
   (D)   A windshield;
   (E)   Brakes and a brake system;
   (F)   A steering mechanism;
   (G)   Appropriate tires that are free of major bumps, bulges, breaks, or any
other unsafe condition;
   (H)   A properly functioning muffler (for internal combustion engines;
   (I)   A license plate bracket (or similar device) mounted to the rear of the
vehicle; and
   (J)   One seat belt per occupant of the vehicle.
(Ord. 2-2022, passed 2-7-22)
§ 75.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of Chapter 75 of the
village's municipal regulations is guilty of and may be charged with a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 18-2021, passed 12-20-21)

§ 76.01 PARKING PROHIBITIONS.
   (Editor’s note: this replaces OBC § 76.04)
   (A)   No person shall stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to
avoid conflict with other traffic or to comply with the provisions of Chapter
76 of these municipal regulations, or while obeying the directions of a police
officer or a traffic-control device, in any of the following places:
      (1)   On a sidewalk, except a bicycle;
      (2)   In front of a public or private driveway;
      (3)   Within an intersection;
      (4)   Within ten feet of a fire hydrant;
      (5)   On a crosswalk;
      (6)   Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection;
      (7)   Within 30 feet of, and upon the approach to, any flashing beacon,
stop sign, or traffic-control device;
      (8)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of
points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a
different length is indicated by a traffic-control device;
      (9)   Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing;
      (10)   Within 20 feet of a driveway entrance to any fire station and, on
the side of the street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within 75
feet of the entrance when it is properly posted with signs;
      (11)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
such standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
      (12)   Alongside any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a
street;
      (13)   Upon any bridge or elevated structure upon a highway, or within a
highway tunnel;
      (14)   At any place where signs prohibit stopping;
      (15)   Within one foot of another parked vehicle;
      (16)   On the roadway portion of a freeway, expressway, or thruway;
      (17)   On bicycle path;
      (18)   On bridle path; or
      (19)   Outside the marked outline of parking spaces in areas so marked
and designated.
   (B)   It shall be illegal to park in any space deemed a no parking zone as
determined by a sign indicating no parking. Any vehicle parking in a no parking
zone shall be ticketed by the Police Department.
   (C)   It shall be illegal to park in any space in excess of the time
indicated on the parking sign. Any vehicle parking for a period of time in
excess of the time indicated on the parking sign shall be ticketed by the
Police Department.
   (D)   All parking prohibitions and regulations contained in Chapter 76 of
these municipal regulations shall apply with equal force on all dedicated
streets, alleys, or public highways within the village, even where reference is
made therein only to streets.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 76.02 PARKING NEAR CURB.
   (Editor’s note: This replaces OBC § 76.05(J) and (K))
   Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway or street within the village
where there is an adjacent curb shall be stopped or parked with the right-hand
wheels of the vehicle parallel with and not more than 12 inches from the right-
hand curb, unless it is impossible to approach so close to the curb, in which
case the stop shall be made as close as possible to the curb as possible and
only for the time necessary to discharge and receive passengers or to load or
unload merchandise.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see §
76.99
§ 76.03 DISPLAYING VEHICLE FOR SALE.
   No person shall park upon a street any vehicle displayed for sale, or
operate or park on any street any vehicle for the primary purpose of displaying
advertising.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see §
76.99
§ 76.04 PARKING OF PLACARDED VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park upon any street any vehicle that is required to be
placarded, whether by virtue of the Ohio Revised Code, regulations promulgated
by the Director of the Ohio Department of Transportation, or regulations
promulgated by the United States Department of Transportation.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see §
76.99
§ 76.05 REPAIRING VEHICLES ON STREETS.
   No person shall park a vehicle on any street for the purpose of repairing,
washing, polishing, or cleaning that vehicle or carry on any of such activities
on any street. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the making of
such necessary emergency repairs as will permit a vehicle to proceed.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see §
76.99
§ 76.06 CONDUCTING BUSINESS FROM PARKED VEHICLE.
   No owner or operator of any vehicle shall use that vehicle or permit it to
be used on the streets and public places of the village for the manufacture or
repair of shoes, clothing, furniture, metal wares, tools, or other articles of
personal or household use.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see §
76.99
§ 76.07 REGISTERED OWNER PRIMA-FACIE LIABLE FOR UNLAWFUL PARKING.
   In any hearing on a charge of illegally parking a motor vehicle, testimony
that a vehicle bearing a certain license plate was found unlawfully parked as
prohibited by Chapter 76 of these municipal regulations, and further testimony
that the record of the state registrar of motor vehicles shows that the license
plate was issued to the defendant, shall be prima-facie evidence that the
vehicle which was unlawfully parked was so parked by the defendant. A certified
registration copy, showing that fact, from the registrar shall be proof of
ownership.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19)
§ 76.08 PARKING TIME LIMITS.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon a public street, alley, or public right
of way for more than 72 consecutive hours.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19) Penalty, see §
76.99
§ 76.09 WAIVER.
   Any person charged with a violation of any provision of Chapter 76 of these
municipal regulations for which payment of a prescribed fine may be made, may
pay that sum in the manner prescribed on the issued traffic ticket. The payment
shall be deemed a plea of guilty, waiver of court appearance, and
acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged offense; and may be accepted in
full satisfaction of the prescribed penalty for the alleged violation. Payment
of the prescribed fine need not be accepted when laws prescribe that a certain
number of such offenses shall require court appearance.
(Ord. 9, 2019, passed 5-6-19)
§ 76.10 PROHIBITION OF PARKING TRAILERS NOT CONNECTED TO A TOW VEHICLE
(UNHITCHED) ON PUBLIC STREETS AND ALLEYS.
   Unhitched trailers may not be parked on village streets or alleys.
(Ord. 15-2021, passed 12-6-21)
§ 76.11 LIMITATION OF ON-STREET PARKING DURING SNOW EMERGENCIES.
   (A)   Whenever, during any period of 24 hours or less, snow falls in the
village or in a section or sections thereof to a depth of two inches or more,
an emergency is declared to exist in that such a heavy snow storm constitutes a
serious public hazard impairing transportation, the movement of food and fuel
supplies, medical care, fire, health and police protection, and other vital
facilities of the village. Such emergency shall continue until an announcement
is made by the Chief of Police that snow plowing has been completed, which
announcement shall be made in the same manner as outlined in division (C)
below.
   (B)   Whenever the Police Chief has good reason to believe, based on weather
forecasts, that a snow storm is approaching meeting the criteria of division
(A) above, either may declare an emergency and the time that such emergency
shall begin.
   (C)   Whenever such emergency exists, or is believed to be imminent under
division (B) above, the Police Chief shall request the cooperation of the local
press and radio stations to announce the emergency and the time that emergency
parking regulations will become effective, which time shall be no sooner than
one hour after the first announcement. Such announcement by one local radio
station or in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the village area
shall constitute notice to the general public of the existence of the
emergency. However, the owners and operators of motor vehicles shall have full
responsibility to determine existing weather conditions and to comply with
emergency parking regulations. All announcements under this division shall also
be posted on the village's website.
   (D)   During the period of the emergency, no person shall park, or cause to
be parked, or permit to be parked or permit to remain parked, or to abandon or
leave unattended any vehicle of any kind or description upon through streets of
the village, being State Route 21, United States Route 62, Canal Street, Market
Street, Wooster Street, Park Street, and Ohio Street, or such other streets as
the Police Chief designates as through streets in the notices provided under
this section. Vehicles may be parked for a period of not longer than three
minutes for actual loading or unloading of passengers or 30 minutes for loading
or unloading of property; provided that no other ordinance restricting parking
as to place or time is violated thereby.
   (E)   Any motor vehicle parked in violation of this prohibition may be
impounded, towed, and stored by the village or by a towing company acting at
the request of the village, at the cost and expense of the owner thereof.
   (F)   In the event the Police Chief is not available to announce an
emergency or the end of an emergency, either the Mayor or Village Administrator
shall have all the same authority as the Police Chief under this section.
   (G)   Notwithstanding the penalties of §
76.99, whoever violates any provision of this section is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on a first offence; on a second offense within one year after the
first offense, the person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree; on
each subsequent offense within one year after the first offense, the person is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 13-2022, passed 5-16-22)
§ 76.12 LIMITATION OF ON-STREET PARKING DURING STREET SWEEPING.
   (A)   From time to time, when the Village Administrator deems it necessary
for the cleaning of village streets, the Village Administrator may designate a
period of one or more days to be street sweeping days, and designate the time
periods during such days when street sweeping parking regulations will be in
effect. The Village Administrator shall request the cooperation of the local
press and radio stations to announce the street sweeping and the dates and
times during which street sweeping shall occur. Such announcement by one local
radio station or in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the village
area shall constitute notice to the general public that parking on village
streets during the period of street sweeping will be regulated. However, the
owners and operators of motor vehicles shall have full responsibility to
determine whether street sweeping is occurring, and to comply with street
sweeping parking regulations. All announcements under this division shall also
be posted on the village's website, and at Village Hall, its police station,
and its Street Department. The village may also utilize secondary means of
notification via the village's managed social media platform, and mailers to
village residents and businesses.
   (B)   During the period of street sweeping, no person shall park, or cause
to be parked, or permit to be parked or permit to remain parked, or to abandon
or leave unattended any vehicle of any kind or description upon the streets of
the village. Vehicles may be parked for a period of not longer than three
minutes for actual loading or unloading of passengers or 30 minutes for loading
or unloading of property; provided that no other ordinance restricting parking
as to place or time is violated thereby.
   (C)   Any motor vehicle parked in violation of this prohibition may be
impounded towed, and stored by the village or by a towing company acting at the
request of the village, at the cost and expense of the owner thereof.
   (D)   Notwithstanding the penalties of §
76.99, whoever violates any provision of this section is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on a first offence; on a second offense within one year after the
first offense, the person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree; on
each subsequent offense within one year after the first offense, the person is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 14-2022, passed 5-16-22)
§ 76.99 PENALTIES.
   (A)   The Police Department shall ticket all violations of Chapter 76 of
these municipal regulations. All tickets for a violation of any portion of this
Chapter 76 shall result in a $20 fine per violation. If a parking ticket is not
paid within ten days of being issued, the fine shall be $25.
   (B)   Any vehicle that is subject to three or more unpaid parking tickets
may be towed by or at the direction of the Police Department, either to the
Police Department parking lot or to a commercial tow yard within ten miles of
Navarre, and said vehicle shall not be released to its owner until the owner
pays the unpaid tickets, the tow bill and any associated costs. The village and
its employees are not liable for any damages to a vehicle that is towed
pursuant to this section.
(Ord. 9-2019, passed 5-6-19)

*EDITOR'S NOTE
   This section contains municipal ordinances which supercede the Ohio Basic
Code section of the same number.
§ 90.01 ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE.
   (A)   No person who is the owner or keeper of dogs, horses, mules, cattle,
bison, sheep, goats, swine, llamas, alpacas, or geese, shall permit them to run
at large in the public road, highway, street, lane, or alley, or upon
unenclosed land, or cause the animals to be herded, kept, or detained for the
purpose of grazing on premises other than those owned or lawfully occupied by
the owner or keeper of such animals.
   (B)   The penalties for violation of this section are as set forth in §
90.99 of this chapter.
   (C)   The owner or keeper of an animal described in division (A) of this
section who negligently permits it to run at large in violation of this section
is liable for all damages resulting from injury, death, or loss to person or
property caused by the animal in any of the places specified in division (A) of
this section or upon the premises of another without reference to the fence
that may enclose the premises.
   (D)   The running at large of any animal specified in division (A) of this
section or upon any of the places specified in division (A) of this section is
prima facie evidence in a civil action for damages that the owner or keeper of
the animal negligently permitted the animal to run at large in violation of
division (A) of this section.
(Ord. 27-2019, passed 1-6-20) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.02 CONFINING ANIMAL FOUND AT LARGE; PUBLICATION OF NOTICE; LIEN.
   A person finding an animal at large in violation of §
90.01 may, and a law enforcement officer on view or information, take and
confine that animal, promptly giving notice of the taking and confining of the
animal to the owner or keeper, if known, and if not known, by publishing a
notice describing the animal once in a newspaper of general circulation within
the village. If the owner or keeper does not appear and claim the animal and
pay the compensation prescribed in §
90.04 for so taking, advertising, and keeping it within ten days from the date
of the notice, that person or the political subdivision whose officer took and
confined the animal shall have a lien for that compensation and the animal may
be sold at public auction as provided in O.R.C. § 1311.49. The residue of the
proceeds of sale shall be paid and deposited by the Clerk-Treasurer in the
general funds of the village.
(Ord. 27-2019, passed 1-6-20)
§ 90.03 UNAVOIDABLE ESCAPES.
   If it is proven that an animal running at large in violation of §
90.01 escaped from its owner or keeper without the owner’s or keeper’s
knowledge or fault, the animal shall be returned to its owner or keeper upon
payment of the compensation describe in §
90.04 for its taking, advertising, and keeping.
(Ord. 27-2019, passed 1-6-20)
§ 90.04 FEES.
   The person or political subdivision whose law enforcement officer takes an
animal running at large in violation of §
90.01 is entitled to receive from the owner or keeper of the animal the
following compensation:
   (A)   For taking and advertising each dog, horse, mule, head of cattle,
bison, swine, sheep, goat, llama, alpaca or goose, $10; and
    (B)   Reasonable expenses actually incurred for keeping each such animal.
(Ord. 27-2019, passed 1-6-20)
§ 90.05 QUARANTINE ORDERS OF MAYOR.
   Whenever the mayor shall deem it necessary for the protection of the public,
he shall issue an order prohibiting, for a certain time, any dog from being at
large in any public street or place, unless muzzled and on leash, so as
effectually to prevent it from biting any person or animal. This order shall be
posted in 3 conspicuous places in the municipality, for such time as the mayor
deems necessary, and any dog found at large during the existence of this
quarantine order shall be impounded and may be destroyed by municipal authority
without notice to the owner.
(Ord. 814, passed 11-19-63)
§ 90.06 INTERFERING WITH ENFORCEMENT OF QUARANTINE ORDERS.
   No person shall molest or interfere with any officer while engaged in
enforcing an order issued under §
90.05.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
90.99
Cross-reference:
   Keeping certain animals, see § 93.51
§ 90.16 LOUD DOG.
   (A)   No person shall keep or harbor any dog within the village which, by
frequent and habitual barking, howling, or yelping, creates unreasonably loud
and disturbing noises of such a character, intensity, and duration as to
disturb the peace, quiet, and good order of the village. Continuous barking,
howling, or yelping for 15 consecutive minutes by such dog, whether confined
inside a residence or building or to the outside area, shall be deemed to have
disturbed the peace, quiet, and good order of the village, provided that at the
time of a complaint, no person or persons were trespassing or threatening to
trespass upon the private property of the owner or resident, and provided that
the dog was not being teased or provoked in any unreasonable manner. Any person
who allows any dog habitually to remain or be lodged or fed within any
residence, building, yard, or enclosure, which that person occupies or owns,
shall be considered to be harboring that dog.
   (B)   Upon an initial complaint, an enforcement officer shall warn the
person in writing of the violation. Upon a second such complaint within 30
days, the enforcement officer shall charge the person with a violation of this
section.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75; Am. Ord. 22-2019, passed 11-18-19) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.17 COLORING RABBITS AND BABY POULTRY; SALE OR DISPLAY OF POULTRY.
   No person shall dye or otherwise color any rabbit or baby poultry,
including, but not limited to, chicks and ducklings. No person shall sell,
offer for sale, expose for sale, raffle or give away any rabbit or baby poultry
which has been dyed or otherwise colored. No poultry younger than four weeks of
age may be sold, given away or otherwise distributed to any person in lots of
less than six. Stores, shops, vendors and others offering young poultry for
sale or other distribution shall provide and operate brooders or other heating
devices that may be necessary to maintain poultry in good health, and shall
keep adequate food and water available to the poultry at all times.
(R.C. § 925.62) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.25 REGISTRATION OF DOGS REQUIRED.
   No owner, keeper, or harborer of a dog more than three months of age, nor
owner of a dog kennel, shall fail to file an application for registration
required by R.C. § 955.01, nor shall he fail to pay the legal fee therefor.
(R.C. § 955.21) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.26 HINDERING CAPTURE OF UNREGISTERED DOG.
   No person shall obstruct or interfere with anyone lawfully engaged in
capturing an unregistered dog or making an examination of a dog wearing a tag.
(R.C. § 955.24) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.27 UNLAWFUL TAGS.
   No person shall own, keep, or harbor a dog wearing a fictitious, altered or
invalid registration tag, or a registration tag not issued by the county
auditor in connection with the registration of such animal.
(R.C. § 955.25) Penalty, see §
90.99
§ 90.28 CATS AND OTHER DOMESTIC ANIMALS AT LARGE, OTHER THAN DOGS.
   (A)   No person, being the owner of or having charge of any cat or other
domestic animal, other than a dog, whether wearing a registration tag or
microchip or not, shall permit such other domestic animal to run at large upon
any public place or on the premises of another.
   (B)   Any cat or other domestic animal, other than a dog, found running at
large or on the premises of another, that is not identified by a registration
tag or microchip shall be presumed to be feral, and may be trapped by any
person, whether or not employed by the village, and delivered to a cat or other
domestic animal shelter within Stark County, Ohio, or in an adjacent county in
the event the Stark County shelter is closed or not taking cats at the time.
   (C)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. A
second violation within one year is a fourth degree misdemeanor.
(Ord. 12-2023, passed 8-21-23)
§ 90.38 EXCRETA REMOVAL.
   (A)   The owner, keeper, or other person having charge of any animal shall
be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by any such animal on a
public walk, street or right of way, recreation or park area or private
property other than that persons' own private property.
   (B)   A person violating this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 10-2020, passed 7-6-20)
§ 90.99(A),(B) PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which another
penalty is not specifically provided, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (B)   Whoever violates the provisions of §
90.06 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense; for each subsequent
offense such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(R.C. § 955.99(B)) (Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75)

*EDITOR'S NOTE
   This section contains municipal ordinances which supercede the Ohio Basic
Code section of the same number.
§ 93.11 WHEN HABITATIONS ARE DEEMED UNSANITARY.
   (A)   A structure, building, or any portion thereof used for human
habitation shall be deemed to be in unclean and unsanitary condition when any
of the following conditions exist:
      (1)   Infection with communicable disease;
      (2)   Absence of the toilet facilities required by law or ordinance;
      (3)   Presence of sewer gas;
      (4)   Dampness or wetness;
      (5)   Lack of repair;
      (6)   Accumulation of dirt, filth, litter, refuse, or other offensive or
dangerous substances or liquids;
      (7)   Defective, unrepaired, or improperly used drainage, plumbing, or
ventilation;
      (8)   The existence of any nuisance or other condition likely to cause
sickness among the occupants.
   (B)   Any structure, building, or any portion thereof, used for human
habitation, which is in such unclean or unsanitary condition is declared to be
a public nuisance.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
§ 93.12 ORDER FOR ABATEMENT OR VACATION OF PREMISES; HEARING.
   (A)   Whenever the board of health of the county ascertains from examination
or reports of its inspectors, sanitary officers, or otherwise that a public
nuisance, as defined in §
93.11 exists in or upon any structure, building, or portion thereof, and is of
the opinion that the nuisance is capable of being abated without immediate
vacation of the premises or that portion thereof, and serves notice upon the
owner of the house, or his lessee or agent, or the person in possession,
charge, or control thereof, directing him to abate the nuisance and remove the
unclean or unsanitary conditions within such reasonable time as may be fixed by
the board and specified in the notice, it shall then be the duty of the owner,
agent, or person to abate the nuisance within such time.
   (B)   Whenever the abatement does not take place within such time; or
whenever, in the opinion of the board, the abatement is impossible or
impracticable without an immediate vacation of the house or portion thereof;
and the board serves notice upon the owner, lessee, agent, or person in
possession, charge or control thereof to vacate or cause the vacation of the
house or portion thereof designated in the notice; then it shall be the duty of
the owner, lessee, agent, or person to vacate or cause the vacation of the
house or portion thereof within 20 days from the date of the service of the
notice, or within a shorter time (not less than 24 hours in any case) as may be
specified in the notice.
   (C)   Whenever, either in addition to or without the service of the notices
on the owner, lessee, agent, or person in possession, charge, or control, the
board is of the opinion that the nuisance can be abated by a tenant or other
occupant of the house or portion thereof; and the notices, either for abatement
of the nuisance or for vacation of the premises, are served upon the tenant or
other occupant, then it shall be the duty of the tenant or other occupant to
comply with the terms of the notices and to abate the nuisance or vacate the
premises accordingly.
   (D)   After any such notice or order of vacation no person shall occupy or
permit the occupancy of the premises or portion thereof until the nuisance has
been completely abated and the building or portion thereof has been rendered
clean and sanitary in accordance with the terms of the notices of the board.
   (E)    When there is no owner, agent, lessee, or person in charge,
possession, or control who is a resident of or can be served in the
municipality, then personal service outside of the municipality may be made on
any such owner, agent, lessee, or person in charge, possession, or control by
anyone delegated by the board to make such service, or by registered letter; or
if the address of the owner, lessee, agent, or person in possession, charge, or
control is unknown or service is not secured by registered letter after effort
to do so, by notice by publication once a week for two consecutive weeks in any
newspaper of general circulation in the municipality, or by posting or
attaching to or on the outside of the structure or building a copy of the
notice or order consecutively for two weeks. This service shall have the same
effect as service within the municipality.
   (F)   When the notice or order of vacation follows a notice or order of
abatement, as provided in divisions (A) through (E) above, the notice or order
of vacation shall not be enforced as provided in this chapter unless it
specifies a time when the person so notified or ordered may appear before the
board of health or officer issuing the same to show cause why the order or
notice of vacation should not be issued, and unless the board, or a majority
thereof, or officer is present at its or his office at the time so specified,
that time to be not less than 24 hours after the service of the notice or
order. When the notice or order of vacation is issued as provided in divisions
(A) through (E) above, without a previous notice or order of abatement, the
notice or order of vacation shall not be enforced as provided in this chapter
unless it specifies a time, not less than five days after the service thereof,
when the person so notified or ordered may appear before the board issuing the
same to show cause why the notice or order should not be enforced, and the
board, or a majority thereof, is present at its office at the time so
specified. However, when, in the opinion of at least four-fifths of the members
of such Board, an emergency exists which requires, for the protection of the
health of occupants, the vacation of the building or portion thereof without a
delay of five days, then no such fixing of a time for hearing shall be
required.   
   (G)   Whenever such procedure, in the opinion of the board of health, is
desirable or necessary, the board may affix conspicuously on the buildings or
part thereof the notice or order of vacation.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.13 ENFORCEMENT OF VACATION ORDER.
   When the notice or order of vacation has not been complied with, and the
board of health certifies such fact to the police chief of the municipality,
together with a copy of the order of notice, it shall be the duty of the police
chief to enforce such notice or order of vacation and to cause the premises to
be vacated in accordance with the terms of the notice or order.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
§ 93.14 ENFORCEMENT THROUGH COURT PROCEEDINGS.
   Whenever the board of health certifies to the solicitor any failure to
comply with any order or notice of vacation, with the request that civil
proceedings for the enforcement thereof be instituted, the solicitor shall
institute any and all proceedings, either legal or equitable, that may be
appropriate or necessary for the enforcement of the order or notice and the
abatement of the nuisance against which the order or notice was directed. These
suits or proceedings shall be brought in the name of the municipality.
Proceedings under this section shall not relieve any party defendant from
criminal prosecution or punishment under this code or any other criminal law or
ordinance in force within the municipality.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
§ 93.15 SANITARY CONDITIONS IN HOTELS, LODGING HOUSES, AND THE LIKE.
   Every owner of, and every agent in charge of, a tenement house, lodging
house, tourist home, tourist cabin, or hotel, or part thereof, shall cause to
be kept thoroughly clean all parts of the premises not within the occupied
apartments. No person shall place filth, urine, or fecal matter in any place
other than that provided therefor, or keep filth, urine, or fecal matter in his
apartments or upon his premises such length of time as to create a nuisance,
and no tenant shall fail to keep his apartment in a clean and sanitary
condition. The walls of courts and shafts, unless built in a light color brick
or stone, shall be thoroughly whitewashed or painted a light color and shall be
so maintained. The whitewash or paint shall be renewed as required by the board
of health.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.16 ORDERS TO CLEAN UP PREMISES; INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Prior to May 10 in every year, the mayor or other chief administrative
officer shall cause a notice or proclamation to be inserted in one or more
newspapers of general circulation within the municipality, ordering persons to
clean thoroughly and provide proper drainage for all lands, yards, vaults,
cesspools, sheds, and barns, and to cause all tin cans, trash and other unclean
and unsightly matter to be removed therefrom on or before May 10.
   (B)   Thereafter in the month of May of each year, the county health officer
or, in his absence, the chief of police shall make a thorough sanitary
inspection of all public and private property in the municipality, and shall
transmit his report together with his recommendations to council on or before
June 1. A copy of the report shall also be sent to the state department of
health.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63)
§ 93.17 ORDERS FOR ABATEMENT.
   (A)   If, upon inspection, it is found that the published order has not been
complied with as to any lot or parcel of ground, council shall, by resolution,
direct the owner, occupant, or person in charge of that land to abate the
nuisance within ten days, setting forth the nature of the violation and the
acts required to be done. The resolution shall provide that upon failure or
refusal to comply with the order, the work required will be done by the
municipality, with the amount expended therefor to be a valid claim against the
owner or occupant, charged as a lien upon the land and recovered by the
municipality by suit in a court of competent jurisdiction.
   (B)   A copy of the resolution adopted under division (A) above may be
served personally or at the usual place of residence of such owner, occupant,
or person in charge of the land, or by registered mail, or, in lieu of such
service, may be published for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general
circulation in the village.
§ 93.20 LOCATION OF PRIVY VAULTS, CESSPOOLS AND SEPTIC TANKS.
   No owner, occupant, or person in charge of any premises so situated as to
permit connection with any sanitary sewer shall maintain or permit to be
maintained on or in connection with such premises any privy vault, cesspool,
septic tank, or other repository for human excreta.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
93.99
Statutory reference:
   Power of municipality to regulate water closets and privies, R.C. § 715.40
   Power of municipality to regulate refuse disposal, R.C. § 715.43
§ 93.21 UNSANITARY VAULTS.
   No person being the owner, lessor, occupant, or person in charge of any
premises upon which a privy vault, cesspool, or septic tank is located shall
permit such vault, pool, or tank, or any building, fixture, or device
appurtenant thereto, to become foul, noisome, filthy, or offensive to
neighboring property owners.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.22 REMOVAL OF CONTENTS OF VAULT.
   Whenever any part of the waste in any privy vault or cesspool extends to a
point less than two feet below the surface of the ground adjacent thereto, or
whenever use of any such vault or cesspool is abandoned or where such use or
maintenance is prohibited by ordinance or health order, the owner, lessor,
occupant or person in charge of such premises shall cause the vault or cesspool
to be emptied of its contents, thoroughly cleaned, and disinfected, and if
abandoned, to be filled with clean earth or mineral matter to the level of the
adjacent ground.
(Ord. 874, passed 11-19-63) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.28(F) POWER OF THE CITY TO FILL OR DRAIN LAND.
   (F)   No person shall fail to comply with the following requirements within
the lawful time after service or publication of the notice or resolution is
made as required by law: To fill or drain any lot or land or remove all putrid
substances therefrom, or remove all obstructions from culverts, covered drains
or natural watercourses as provided in divisions (B) through (E) of this
section.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.40 KEEPING DOWN WEEDS.
   (A)   No person owning or having charge of land within the village, shall
fail to keep said property free and clear from all noxious weeds and rank
vegetation or fail to cut all such weeds and vegetation on the lots owned or
controlled by him when such weeds or vegetation reach a height of nine inches.
(Ord. 16-68, passed 6-18-68)
   (B)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with this section five days after
service of notice by the mayor or any police officer, as provided in §
93.41, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
('75 Code, § 678.01(b)) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.41 NOTICE TO OWNER TO CUT NOXIOUS WEEDS; SERVICE.
   Upon information that noxious weeds are growing on lands in the municipality
and are about to spread or mature seeds, the mayor or any police officer shall
cause written notice to be served on the owner or person having charge of that
land that those weeds must be cut and destroyed within five days after service
of notice. If the owner or person having charge of such land is a nonresident
whose address is known, the notice shall be sent to his address by registered
mail; if unknown, it shall be sufficient to publish the notice once in a
newspaper of general circulation in the county.
('75 Code, § 678.02)
§ 93.52 OPEN BURNING.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "GARAGE." Any matter resulting from the handling, processing, preparation,
cooking, and consumption of food or food products.
   "LANDSCAPE WASTE." Any vegetable or plant matter except garbage, including
trees, tree trimmings, branches, stumps, brush, weeds, leaves, grass,
shrubbery, yard trimmings, and crop residues.
   "OPEN BURNING." The burning of any materials wherein air contaminants
resulting from combustion are emitted directly into the air, without passing
through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber. For purposes of this
definition, an enclosed chamber is one which has only those ducts, stacks, or
chimneys necessary to provide combustion air and to permit the escape of
exhaust gas. The burning of any materials in metal cans, barrels, containers,
wire baskets, or any homemade device is "OPEN BURNING." The burning of
materials in incinerators is governed by state environmental protection agency
regulations AP-3-10 and EP-11-0l to EP-11-13.
   (B)   No person shall cause or allow open burning within the municipality
except as provided in divisions (C) through (E) hereof.
   (C)   Fires allowed by this division shall not be used to burn garbage,
landscape waste, or any other waste material. They may be used for heating tar,
welding, acetylene torches, highway safety flares, heating for warmth of
outdoor workers, smudge posts, and similar occupational needs. They may also be
used for bonfires, campfires, and outdoor fireplace equipment, whether for
cooking food for human consumption, pleasure, religious, ceremonial, warmth,
recreational and similar purposes, if the following conditions are met:
      (1)   They are fueled with clean seasoned firewood, natural gas or
equivalent, or any clean burning fuel with emissions that are equivalent to or
lower than those created from the burning of seasoned firewood;
      (2)   They are not used for waste disposal purposes; and
      (3)   They shall have a total fuel area of three feet or less in diameter
and two feet or less in height.
   (D)   Fires allowed by this division shall not be used to burn garbage,
landscape waste or any other waste material. The fuel used shall be a clean
fuel, that is, a fuel chosen to minimize the generation and emission of air
contaminants. Open burning shall be allowed for the following purposes with
prior notification to both the municipal fire department and the district
office of the state environmental protection agency, as provided by state
environmental protection agency regulation EP-12-05:
      (1)   Prevention or control of disease or pests.
      (2)   Ceremonial purposes. Ceremonial fires shall be less than five feet
by five feet by five feet and shall burn no longer than three hours.
   (E)   Open burning shall be allowed for the following purposes upon receipt
of written permission from the district office of the state environmental
protection agency, provided that any conditions specified in the permit are
followed. Receipt of written permission shall be obtained as provided by state
environmental protection agency regulation EP-12-05.
      (1)   Disposal of hazardous or toxic materials where the state
environmental protection agency determines that there is no practical alternate
method of disposal.
      (2)   Instruction in methods of fire fighting or for research in the
control of fire.
      (3)   In emergency or other extraordinary circumstances for any purpose
determined to be necessary by the state environmental protection agency.
   (F)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor. In addition, the offender shall be required to pay the cost
of proper disposal of the material burned. The cost of proper disposal of the
materials burned shall be the amount it would have cost to dispose of the
materials in a manner that is consistent with the air, water, and solid waste
laws, ordinances, and regulations of the municipality and the state.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75; Am. Ord. 22-2019, passed 11-18-19) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.53 NOISE.
   (A)   No person shall make, cause, suffer, allow or permit to be made within
the village, any unreasonably loud, annoying, disturbing and unnecessary noise
or noises of such character, intensity and/or duration to be detrimental to the
life, health, and right to peace and enjoyment to any individual. Loud,
disturbing and/or unnecessary noises in violation of this section shall
include, but are not limited to, the following:
      (1)   The sounding of any horn, bell, or other signal or warning device
on any motor vehicle, except as a danger or warning signal.
      (2)   No person shall play or allow to be played, music, amplifying
sound, radio, music player, television, audio system or musical instrument in
such a manner or at such volume or intensity to annoy or disturb the peace and
quiet, comfort, and/or repose of neighboring inhabitants or those who claim
noise is audible within 150 feet of said sound source having due regard for the
proximity of places of residence, hospital or other residential institutions
and to any other conditions affected by such noises or at a volume which is
audible within 150 feet of said sound source or till persons other than those
who are in the vehicle, structure, or room in which such device or instrument
is played and are voluntary listeners thereof.
      (3)   The making of any unnecessary or unseemly noise by a person
including operation of any instrument, device, agency, or vehicle within 150
feet of any school, courthouse, church, or building in which religious services
are held, during school hours, hours of court, or hours of public worship,
respectively.
   (B)   A violation shall be deemed to have occurred when any person makes,
causes, suffers, allows or permits to be made within the village, any
unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise or noises as described in
this legislation.
(Ord. 10-2010, passed 12-20-10)
§ 93.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this Chapter 93, for which no
penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during which a violation continues
or occurs.
(Ord. 22-2019, passed 11-18-19)
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS

 95.99   Penalty
*EDITOR'S NOTE
   This section contains municipal ordinances which supercede the Ohio Basic
Code section of the same number.
§ 95.01 CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO IMPROVING STREETS.
   No department of the village shall accept, lay out, open, improved grade,
pave, curb or light any street or other way, unless the street or way has been
accepted or opened or otherwise has received the legal status of a public
street or way or unless the street or way corresponds in location and extent
with a street or way shown on a recorded plat which has been legally accepted
by council.
(Ord. 814, passed 11-19-63)
Statutory reference:
   Power of the municipality over streets and sidewalks, R.C. §§ 715.19, 717.01
(P), 723.01, 723.011, 723.02, 729.01
§ 95.02 OPENING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the village administrator,
the village engineer, or the authorized employees or agents of either, to make
any opening in any street, alley, sidewalk, or public right-of-way of the
municipality unless a permit to make the opening has been obtained prior to
commencement of the work, as provided in § 95.03.
(Ord. 12-70, passed 1-5-71; Am. Ord. 5-2015, passed 3-2-15) Penalty, see §
 95.99
§ 95.03 APPLICATION AND CASH DEPOSIT.
   Each permit for making an opening shall be confined to a single project and
shall be issued by the village administrator. Application shall be in a form
prescribed by council, giving the exact location of the proposed opening, the
kind of paving, the area and depth to be excavated, and such other facts as may
be provided for. The permit shall be issued only after a cash deposit as
provided for in §
95.04 has been made with the clerk-treasurer and conditioned upon prompt and
satisfactory refilling of excavations and restoration of all surfaces
disturbed. The village administrator shall have the discretion to require the
applicant to enter into a written agreement, on a form approved by the village
solicitor, requiring the applicant to meet certain time and quality time
standards and providing for stipulated liquidated delay damages, of up to $100
per opening per day, that would be in addition to any repair costs incurred
under §
95.04, and any penalties under §
95.99.
(Ord. 12-70, passed 1-5-71; Am. Ord. 21-1975, passed 9-2-75; Am. Ord. 5-2015,
passed 3-2-15)
§ 95.04 DEPOSIT REQUIRED; RESTORATION SPECIFICATIONS.
   No person desiring to open any of the public ways in the village shall fail
to comply with the following provisions:
   (A)   For the opening of any public street, highway or sealed alley within
the village, a cash deposit of $1,000 per opening shall be paid to the clerk-
treasurer. After the opening to the street, highway, or sealed alley has been
properly repaired to the satisfaction of the village administrator or his duly
authorized representative, the deposit shall be returned. The village
administrator has the discretion, with respect to multiple opening projects, to
waive all or part of a deposit above $1,000, based on the applicant’s past
dealings with the village or the applicant’s known financial responsibility. If
the street, highway, or sealed alley is not property repaired, the village
shall cause the work to be done with the $1,000 deposit, pursuant to the
specifications in divisions (B), (C), and (D) hereof and return any unused
portion of such deposit. The applicant shall be responsible to the village to
the extent the village’s cost of repair exceeds the amount of the deposit.
   (B)   No excavation shall be more than 36 inches in width. The restoration
of the excavation shall be as follows:
      (l)   All dirt removed during the course of excavating shall be removed
from the site of the excavation.
      (2)   The pipe placed in the excavation shall be covered with 12 inches
of coarse sand and the remainder of the excavation shall be fill¢d to within
eight inches of the existing road surface with pea gravel (or with No. 46
gravel).
      (3)   A minimum of six inches of concrete shall cover such gravel and a
minimum of two inches of hot-mix blacktop shall cover the concrete to the
existing road level.
   (C)   In the opening of an unsealed alley, the applicant shall restore that
alley to the condition it was in before the work was begun and cover it with
gravel. No deposit shall be required for the opening of any unsealed alley.
   (D)   All excavations and openings in any public ways in the village shall
be completed for each individual installation on the same day in which the
excavation or opening is made, unless permission has been granted by the mayor
or his duly authorized representative to do otherwise.
(Ord. 13-70, passed 1-5-71; Am. Ord. 26-1979, passed 12-4-79; Am. Ord. 8-1986,
passed 7-1-86; Am. Ord. 5-2015, passed 3-2-15) Penalty, see §
 95.99
§ 95.05 BARRIERS AND WARNING LIGHTS AROUND EXCAVATIONS.
   (A)   Any person engaged in or employing others in excavating, or opening
any street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way, shall have the excavation or
opening fully barricaded at all times to prevent injury to persons or animals.
   (B)   No person shall abandon or knowingly permit to remain on public or
private property any excavation, well, cesspool, or structure which is in the
process of construction, reconstruction, repair, or alteration unless the same
is adequately protected by suitable barricades and guarded by warning devices
or lights at night so that the condition will not reasonably prove dangerous to
life or limb.
   (C)   No person shall destroy, remove, damage or extinguish any barricade or
warning light that is placed for the protection of the public so as to prevent
injury to life or limb.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75)
§ 95.06 SUPERVISION AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   The streets and alleys committee is hereby charged with the duty of
overseeing all sidewalks within the village limits, which shall specifically
include the inspection of existing sidewalks, the reporting of any necessary
repairs to council, the supervision of repairs or construction of new
sidewalks, and the establishment of detailed specifications for sidewalks and
the location of new sidewalks. In establishing these specifications and
locations, the committee shall attempt, insofar as possible, to establish
uniformity throughout the village, seeking maximum utility with a minimum of
damage to property and those trees, shrubbery, and fences already located
thereon.
   (B)   Unless special circumstances justify different specifications in
constructing new sidewalks, the specifications shall call for concrete
sidewalks of a minimum width of five feet and a minimum depth of four inches,
upon sound footing. Any deviation from the above specifications shall be
subject to the prior approval of the committee. In the locating of sidewalks,
the committee shall not be limited to village property or street right of ways,
but may specify locations upon private property.
(Ord. 7-1974, passed 5-21-74)
§ 95.07 SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION; ASSESSMENTS.
   (A)   Council may designate by resolution specific areas within the village
where new sidewalks shall be constructed, pursuant to the detailed
specifications of the streets and alleys committee. The resolution may provide
that the cost of the construction shall be borne by the village, in which case
the resolution shall call for proper advertisement for bids as provided by law;
or the resolution may provide that the cost thereof be assessed against the
owners of the property bounding or abutting the proposed sidewalks.
   (B)   If council elects to assess the cost of the repair or construction of
sidewalks, it shall, by resolution, specify the particular sidewalks to be
repaired or constructed.
      (1)   Appropriate written notice of the resolution shall thereupon be
served upon the owner or agent of the owner of each parcel of land abutting on
the sidewalk by the chief of police or a patrolman, as provided in R.C. §§
729.02 and 729.03. If the owner of a parcel is a nonresident, notice of the
resolution shall be given by publication, as provided by R.C. § 729.03.
      (2)   The notice shall state that if the indicated repairs are not made
within 30 days or the indicated construction is not completed within 60 days,
or within a reasonable extension thereof expressly granted by the streets and
alleys committee, the village shall perform or contract for the repair and
construction on behalf of the owner and shall report and assess the cost
thereof upon the owner.
      (3)   The assessed cost thereof may include the cost of labor or
materials furnished by the village. However, the cost of sidewalks abutting
publicly-owned property and the cost of cross-over or intersection sidewalks
shall be paid by the village and no part thereof shall be assessed.
      (4)   Council may provide for the construction of sidewalks on only one
side of a street or alley and it may assess the cost thereof, equally or
otherwise, upon the owners of the property abutting on both sides of such
street or alley.
      (5)   The assessed cost shall constitute a lien on such property from the
date the amount thereof is reported to the owner; if the cost is not paid to
the clerk-treasurer within ten days thereafter, the clerk-treasurer shall
certify it to the county auditor, who shall place it upon the tax duplicate and
collect the same as provided by law.
   (C)   Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as preventing
council from providing for the repair or construction of sidewalks and
recovering the cost thereof by special assessments, as provided by R.C. §
727.01 et seq.
(Ord. 7-1974, passed 5-21-74)
§ 95.08 REPAIRS.
   The streets and alleys committee shall report all necessary repairs of
specific sidewalks, together with its recommendations thereon, to council.
Council may provide for the repair and restoration thereof or of any portion
thereof at the expense of the village, or may direct that the owner of the
abutting property shall repair the same, according to the detailed
specifications of the committee.
(Ord. 7-1974, passed 5-21-74)
§ 95.09 STREET AND SIDEWALK OBSTRUCTION.
   (A)   No person shall obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public
way within the municipality, by erecting thereon any fence or building, or
permitting any fence or building to remain thereon. Each day that any such
fence or building is permitted to remain upon such public way shall be deemed a
separate offense.
   (B)   No person shall place or knowingly drop upon any part of a sidewalk or
playground any tacks, bottles, wire, glass, nails, or other articles which may
damage property of another or injure any person or animal traveling along or
upon that sidewalk or playground.
   (C)   No person shall walk on, or allow any animal upon, or injure or deface
in any way any soft or newly laid sidewalk pavement.
   (D)   No person shall place, deposit, or maintain any merchandise, goods,
material, or equipment upon any sidewalk so as to obstruct pedestrian traffic
thereon except for such reasonable time as may be actually necessary for the
delivery or pickup of those articles. In no case shall the obstruction remain
on such sidewalk for more than one hour.
   (E)   No person shall unload upon, or transport any heavy merchandise,
goods, material, or equipment over or across any sidewalk or curb without first
placing some sufficient protection over the pavement to protect against damage
or injury.
   (F)   No person shall allow any cellar or trap door, coal chute for elevator
or lift-opening in any sidewalk to remain open without providing suitable
safeguards to protect and warn pedestrian traffic of the dangerous conditions.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
95.99
Cross-reference:
   Driving upon sidewalk prohibited, §
72.58
§ 95.14 FENCES.
   (A)   No person shall erect or maintain any fence charged with electrical
current.
   (B)   No person shall erect or maintain a barbed wire fence which abuts or
is adjacent to any public street or sidewalk. This division does not prevent
the placement and use of not more than three strands of barbed wire on top of a
fence other than a barbed wire fence, provided such strands are not less than
72 inches from the ground. Barbed wire partition fences may be erected and
maintained as provided in R.C. § 971.03.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.20 PLANTING IN PUBLIC WAYS; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall plant any tree or shrub upon any street, alley, or other
public way unless he has first obtained a permit to do so in writing from the
mayor, which permit shall specify the size, type, species, and proposed
location of the tree or shrub to be planted.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.21 DENIAL OF PERMIT.
   The mayor shall have the authority to deny a permit to any person who
proposes to plant any tree or shrub upon a street, alley, or other public way
of a size, type, or species found to be undesirable by the shade tree
commission or found to be undesirable for the location proposed. He shall also
have the authority to deny a permit to any person who proposes to plant any
tree or shrub at a location found by the commission to be unsuitable for the
planting of that tree or shrub.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71)
Cross-reference:
   Shade tree commission, §§ 36.25 through 36.29
§ 95.22 TRIMMING AND REMOVAL.
   Trimming and removal of trees in any street, alley, or other public way
shall be completed pursuant to the following provisions:
   (A)   No topping or dehorning of trees shall be permitted without the
written permission of the mayor. (Ord. 10-1972, passed 3-7-72)
   (B)   Whenever possible, all small, established, standard trees shall be
trimmed of branches to a height of at least seven feet from the ground, the
first branch to be not over nine feet from the ground. Newly planted small
trees need not have all the lower branches removed until they are well
established. All large established trees shall be trimmed to sufficient height
to allow free passage of pedestrians and vehicular traffic as follows: ten feet
over all streets, and 16 feet over principal traffic thoroughfares.
   (C)   All cuts shall be made with a saw or pruner and only at nodes or
crotches. No stubs shall be left. No spurs or climbing irons shall be used in
the trees.
   (D)   All dead, cross, and rubbing limbs shall be removed.
   (E)   All old and new wounds over one inch in diameter shall be treated with
a good quality tree-wound dressing unless decay of the tree is apparent.
   (F)   All tools which are used on a tree suspected of being infected with a
contagious disease shall be thoroughly disinfected before being used on another
tree.
   (G)   All trees to be removed shall be cut at least eight inches below the
ground, the soil shall be replaced and the area leveled.
(Ord. 22-71, passed 6-1-71) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter, for which another
penalty is not already provided, shall be fined not more than $150. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
   (B)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of §§
95.02 through
95.04 is guilty of failing to comply with village excavation requirements, a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 26-1979,
passed 12-4-79)
   (C)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of §§
95.05,
95.09, or
95.14 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 3-1975, passed 1-7-75; Am. Ord. 5-2015, passed 3-2-15)
